Thank you for following our real-time updates! Good night everyone – from the PMO team :)

#ndrsg

PM Lee: At the National Day Parade, there were two special moments for me.

One was when Kit Chan sang “Home” and we sang together so loudly from all around the Padang that we could hear ourselves.

The second moment was when I met the kids in the bright LED costumes on the Padang after the parade. They were in high spirits and their faces shone with excitement and hope. I thought to myself, these are the faces of the future of Singapore. 

At SG100, these kids will be about 60 years old. I hope they will be back at the Padang celebrating again, remembering SG50, congratulating each other on how far they have come, and looking at more young, radiant faces of children and many grandchildren, and singing Majulah Singapura!

#ndrsg

(Photo by PM Lee)

PM: Nobody can be sure or promise that Singapore will still be doing well come SG100. 

After Mr Lee Kuan Yew died, one of his friends wrote to me. She described a dinner conversation that took place during a gathering of Mr Lee and his old friends in January 2015, shortly before he was hospitalised.

His friends had asked him: “Will there be a Singapore 50 years from now?” He said: “Of course there will be … even better!” 

#ndrsg #rememberingleekuanyew #rememberinglky

(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

PM: My team and I take very seriously our responsibility to make sure Singapore lasts beyond us. My core team are already in our 50s and early 60s. We must have the next team ready in the wings.

Will Singapore stay special for our children?
- A multi-racial society strengthened by diversity, not splintered by divisions 
- A rugged society where everyone strives to do his best, but looks out for his fellow men
- A people who live up to our song “One People, One Nation, One Singapore”

If you are proud of what we have achieved together and support the future that we are building, please support me and my team, so that together, we can keep Singapore special for the next 50 years.

#ndrsg

PM Lee: In the last ten years, we have written another chapter of the Singapore story.

We said we would build more beautiful homes that Singaporeans could afford, and we did (e.g., Punggol 21 and Dawson).

We said we would strengthen our safety nets, and we did.  We introduced WorkFare, Silver Support and ComCare, built new hospitals, and made healthcare more accessible and affordable (CHAS, PG card, and MediShield Life).

We said we would create more pathways for our children to chase rainbows, and we did:
- NorthLight School (Official) and Assumption Pathway for students who failed their PSLE, because we believe in our young and we will never give up on them
- School of the Arts, Singapore, School of Science and Technology, Singapore to cater to varied talents
- First-class campuses for our Institute of Technical Education, Singapore
- New universities (SUTD Singapore University of Technology & Design, Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT), SIM University (UniSIM))

We said we would transform our city, and we did (Changi Airport Jewel, T4 & T5; Gardens by the Bay, beautiful parks connectors and ABC waterways like Bishan-AMK Park).

We said we would transform Marina Bay and we did. In 2005, Marina South was still empty. At my NDR that year, I promised you Marina Bay would be special by our Jubilee. Today in 2015, Marina Bay is entirely transformed.

We did this together. We had a vision, we believed in it, and together, we realised our dreams.

#ndrsg

(Photo by PM Lee)

THE SINGAPORE SPIRIT

PM: After 50 years, this sense of togetherness and purpose is stronger than before. The Singapore spirit shines when we celebrate our successes together, such as when our athletes made us proud at the SEA Games. Or in times of need when we help one another, like people rushing to help a man run over and stuck under a truck, or Singaporeans in Bangkok who contacted our Bangkok embassy offering their help after the #bangkokblast.

Our spirit shone brightest when Mr Lee Kuan Yew passed away. It brought out so much in us, and on the day of his funeral, we were mourning Mr Lee’s passing, but also affirming what he stood for, and celebrating what he had achieved. That day, something changed in us. Our shared moment of sorrow bonded us and we knew that we were Singaporean.

#ndrsg

(MCI Photo)

FAMILIES AND BABIES

PM Lee: Glad to hear from Grace Fu that we have given out almost 20,000 SG50 Jubilee Baby gifts so far, including one to Tin Pei Ling. I hope couples will continue to have many babies beyond SG50.

Having a child is a major responsibility but we will help you, because every Singaporean child is precious to us. We will do so in four ways:

1. We will help couples live closer to their parents by introducing a Proximity Housing Grant. Every Singaporean household will be eligible, whether first-time buyer or not. You will get the Grant when you buy a resale flat with or near your parents, or your married children.

2. We will increase the amount of the Baby Bonus, and give it for every child. This will provide more support for larger families.

3. We will increase the Medisave Grant for Newborns. It will be enough to cover MediShield Life premiums for the child until age 21, and also help with other healthcare expenses.

4. Fathers play a vital role in bringing up children. You have to do your part. Paternity Leave will be increased from one to two weeks. The Government will pay for the extra week of leave. We will implement it on a voluntary basis first, and the Public Service will volunteer straightway. 

The Baby Bonus, Medisave Grant, and Paternity Leave changes will apply with effect from 1 January 2015.

#ndrsg

(MCI Photo)

ELDERLY WILL ALWAYS HAVE A PLACE IN SINGAPORE

PM: We made the Pioneer Generation Package (PGP) to express our gratitude to the pioneers who contributed so much to building today’s Singapore. PG Ambassadors visited every pioneer in their homes to chat with them, understand their needs, and explain the PGP.

Minister Gan Kim Yong leads the Ministerial Committee on Ageing. He will announce an Action Plan to make Singapore a model for successful ageing. 

One sneak peek from his plan: Many people in their 60s want to work longer. The tripartite partners have been discussing this, and they have reached an agreement. We will pass legislation to raise the re-employment age from 65 to 67 by 2017.

#ndrsg

(Photo courtesy of Pioneer Generation Office)

AFFORDABLE AND ACCESSIBLE HOUSING FOR ALL

PM Lee: We are going to do three more things to keep HDB flats affordable and accessible to all Singaporeans:

1. The income ceiling will be raised from $10,000 to $12,000 for HDB flats, and from $12,000 to $14,000 for ECs, so that more households can buy HDB and ECs. 

2. We will raise the household income ceiling for Special CPF Housing Grants (SHG) from $6,500 to $8,500 so that two-thirds of all first-timer households will qualify. We will also double the maximum SHG from $20,000 to $40,000. 

3. We will help those in rental flats to own a flat. With latest changes, first-timers can still afford a 2-room flat even if you earn below $1,000, if you hold a stable job and contribute to CPF regularly. The Fresh Start Housing Scheme will help second-timer rental households own a 2-room flat. The flat will have a shorter lease and stricter conditions on resale. A Fresh Start Grant will be provided to help pay for the flat. We will support the family with counsellors to guide them to solve their problems holistically. The family has to play its part, and show that they are putting their lives in order.

#ndrsg

PM Lee: There is an African saying: “If you want to go fast, go alone.  If you want to go far, go together”.

HDB housing is one important way we make sure we go together. The HDB home ownership programme has been a tremendous success. Today, more than 90% of HDB households own their flats. 

In Singapore, no matter who you are, you live in a good neighbourhood with good homes, parks and waterways, and you feel safe and secure. This must always be the reality for all Singaporeans.

#ndrsg

The Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) provides applied-learning pathways for students who prefer more hands-on learning. 

We will build a new campus for SIT in Punggol. It will be integrated with a creative industry cluster JTC will build just across the road. Students can go from classroom to workplace and apply what they learn. 

It will also be integrated into Punggol Downtown and HDB’s upcoming Northshore District. The community will share its facilities – classrooms, workshops, and multi-purpose hall.

#ndrsg

PM Lee: SkillsFuture provides Singaporeans opportunities to develop to their full potential, whatever their starting point may be. 

The SkillsFuture Earn-and-Learn Programme gives fresh ITE and Polytechnic graduates a head-start in careers. They earn a full-time salary while learning new skills, so that they can upgrade to higher jobs. We have also created the SkillsFuture Credit. Every Singaporean aged 25 and above will get an initial $500 of credit, with top-ups from time to time, to spend on training programmes throughout life.

PM Lee: We have to be alive to our external environment. We have good relations with our neighbours, but it may not always be like this. Even in the next 10 years, we cannot be sure.

On our National Day, just recently on 9 August, one Indonesian newspaper published an overview of the relationship between Indonesia and Singapore. The article quoted what a senior politician said about the haze: “I would only consider apologising (for the haze) if Singapore and Malaysia are thankful for the oxygen they enjoy (from Indonesian forests) for 11 months (each year)”. This may not reflect the Indonesian Government’s view, but we have to take note of it. It is a deep seated mindset – that a little red dot should know its place in the world. That mindset will not disappear for a long time.

We have to stay on top of regional developments, and watch relations between the major powers in the region. We have been able to maintain our security and standing in the world because we have a strong SAF, successful economy, and good diplomats and leaders. We must maintain and strengthen this if we are to hold our own in the outside world.

#ndrsg

TRUST & GOOD GOVERNMENT

PM Lee: We have kept faith between the Government and the people. As the Government, we have kept our promises. We are honest about the choices we have to make, and do not shy away from hard realities or sugar-coat difficult issues. In turn, the people trust the Government to have their interests at heart and they support its decisions. Therefore, even in tough times, we can act decisively together.

One tough issue we have is immigration and foreigners. Singaporeans understandably have strong views on it. The Government has heard them. But there are no easy choices on this matter. Every option has a downside, and whichever option we choose will involve some pain. 

PM Lee: I believe that I am doing what Singapore needs and what best safeguards your interest. It is my responsibility to make this judgement and act on your behalf.

#ndrsg

SELF-RELIANCE & MUTUAL SUPPORT

PM Lee: We knew right from the start that to strike out and blaze a path on our own, everyone had to pull their weight and be counted. That is why Mr Lee Kuan Yew exhorted us over and over again to become a rugged society. Our people must be robust and tough, able to take hard knocks, always striving to be better. No one owes us a living and we have to make our own way forward. 

But a rugged society doesn’t mean every man for himself. We are strong even though we are small, because we are strong together. The ethos of our society is that if you work hard, you should do well. At the same time, if you do well, we expect you to help others.

We must inculcate this same ethos in our young. That is why we encourage our children to play sports, and send them to adventure learning and character education – to bring up a generation who will grow up tough and able to work closely together.

#ndrsg

(Photo courtesy of National Youth Council – Outward Bound Singapore)

MULTI-RACIALISM

PM Lee: We separated from Malaysia because we believed in the ideal of a multi-racial society. We believed that before race, language, and religion, we should first and foremost, be Singaporean.

We encouraged all the communities to come together, but yet gave each community space to maintain their own cultures and ways of life. When difficult issues arose, we dealt with them together. We made extra effort to ensure that every community could hold their own and not be left behind. 

Therefore, for SG50, every community in Singapore is celebrating because all have progressed with the nation. Each group is celebrating with other groups, because we are one united people.

#ndrsg

(Photo courtesy of NDP 2015 Publications Committee)

What an exhilarating journey these past 50 years have been! Three factors got us here, PM Lee said;

1. Multi-racialism 
2. Self-reliance and mutual support
3. Keeping faith between Government and people

PM Lee thanked Kit Chan for her beautiful rendition of “Home”, and for dedicating her song to the late Mr Lee Kuan Yew. He was touched that she had offered to sing when he invited her to the Rally.

#ndrsg

总理在演讲中把焦点放在国外的发展，提醒大家新加坡所面对的外在威胁。这也是李光耀先生所关心的课题，因为它关系到新加坡长远的利益。

国外局势随时可能影响区域的稳定，从而破坏新加坡的安定，威胁我国的安全，因此国人必须团结一致，才能捍卫国家利益，维护国家安全，确保社会和谐。

总理说，新加坡在这50年来，建国前辈的努力付出造就了今天的新加坡。在这个共同奋斗的过程中，人民和政府之间建立了互信。领导的班子有责任把国家治理好，和人民分享成功的果实。在接下来的50年，新加坡还会是一个闪亮的小红点，再创无数个高峰，迈向辉煌百年。

#ndrsg

(Photo by MCI)

总理说这50年来新加坡取得的成就，华社功不可没。华商领袖积极开创事业，带动经济发展，也负起各种社会责任。华社另一支柱是文教界的许多人士。他们的努力和苦心，让一代又一代新加坡人打下华语基础，发挥双语的优势。

总理也指出，华文媒体工作者对各种课题详细的报道，让不熟悉英文的民众了解国内和世界的动态，以及政府所推行的政策，例如建国一代配套、终身健保计划。总理鼓励大家再接再厉，让华社蓬勃发展，让华族文化更多姿多彩。

在面对生活费这个课题时，总理说，政府在解决衣食住行和医疗费方面，下了很大的功夫。政府接下来会建更多小贩中心，以合作社及社会企业的形式管理。这个形式除了能提供较便宜的食物以外，一部分利润也能用来主办优惠活动，确保大家可享用价廉物美的熟食。

总理也举出许多现有的政策，以减轻国人在交通费和医药费的负担。所有学生 – 包括理工学院的学生 – 都享有优惠车资卡。政府也在今年提供50元的公共交通礼券给60岁以上的乐龄人士。在医疗方面，建国一代配套和终身健保计划也帮助国人省下不少医药费。

Pertama, dana bagi mempertingkat kemahiran guru-guru subjek sekular.

Lui Tuck Yew has told me that he does not wish to stand again in the coming General Election, and I have reluctantly accepted his decision. He had told me this early this year. My senior colleagues and I tried hard to change his mind, and are disappointed that we did not succeed. 

Tuck Yew has done a lot for my team and for Singapore over the last decade, especially these last four years as Minister for Transport. When I asked him to go to MOT in 2011, we both knew that I was giving him a very difficult job, but he did not hesitate. There were urgent things to be done, and public expectations were high. 

He put his heart and soul into the task, and made many improvements to the public transport system. The benefits will be seen in the coming years. The job is not yet complete, but we are heading in the right direction.

Besides Transport, Tuck Yew also served in the Ministries of Information, Communications and the Arts, Foreign Affairs and Defence. As an MP in Moulmein, he has worked to improve the lives of his residents. 

We will miss Tuck Yew. I thank him for all that he has done for Singapore over the last decade, and wish him all the best in future. - LHL

(Midnight visit to SMRT Bishan Depot in May 2015. / MCI File Photo by Terence Tan)

Happy National Day and SG50!

Exactly 50 years ago, a radio announcer read the Proclamation that marked the birth of our nation. This morning, at National Day Observances, we remembered and celebrated that pivotal moment. We heard the Proclamation again, this time read by the late Mr Lee Kuan Yew (in a recording done in 2012). 

We have come far in 50 years. While we enjoy today’s prosperity and progress, never forget how hard we worked to get here. What we have is special and precious, and must never be taken for granted. 

Today we sang Majulah Singapura proudly. To still do so in 50 years’ time, let us work together as one united people, regardless of race, language or religion, for the happiness, prosperity and progress of our nation. – LHL

Amidst SG50 celebrations, I am watching our water stocks closely.

Vivian Balakrishnan visited Linggiu Reservoir in Johor on Monday. The reservoir ensures that there is always enough fresh water in the Johor River to supply PUB’s waterworks downstream at Kota Tinggi.

Because of prolonged dry weather, Linggiu Reservoir is now only half full – lower than it has ever been. (See Vivian’s photos at http://on.fb.me/1KPSSzQ.) If the dry weather continues and Linggiu Reservoir is emptied, PUB will be unable to draw all the water we are entitled to from the Johor River.

I visited Linggiu Reservoir in 2012. (See my post at: http://on.fb.me/1eShI3x.) After my visit, I decided to build more NEWater and desalination plants, to make our water supply more resilient. One more NEWater plant will be completed next year, and a third desalination plant in 2017.

In Singapore, water will always be a precious resource. Never take it for granted, or waste it. Please do your part to conserve water. – LHL

The Electoral Boundaries Review Committee (EBRC) has submitted its report. 

When I appointed the Committee two months ago, I asked it to redraw the constituency boundaries, to have smaller Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs), and at least 12 Single Member Constituencies (SMCs). The Committee was also to take into account population shifts and new towns that have come up.

They have done so. They have added one SMC and one GRC, giving a total of 13 SMCs and 16 GRCs. 

We will have more 4-member GRCs (6 instead of previous 2), and fewer 5-member GRCs (8 instead of 11). 

To make smaller GRCs and more SMCs, some boundaries have had to be changed. This will be the electoral configuration in the next general election. 

Wherever the boundaries may be drawn, MPs should serve the residents they represent to the best of their ability. And voters should support the candidates or teams who will best represent their interests, both in the constituency and as the government of Singapore.

More details on the Committee’s report at: http://bit.ly/1HNcAbA

– LHL

Answered a question today on Singapore’s role in sustainable development. This was in a dialogue at the FutureChina Global Forum organised by 通商中国 Business China.

I joked that Singapore is such a small country that even if we all stopped breathing it would make little difference to climate change. More seriously, we have few options for renewable energy. There is no space for nuclear power, and other sources are either not feasible (wind, hydro) or limited in scale (solar), so we have to rely heavily on fossil fuels.

But we will be a responsible member of the global community, and help to build consensus on an international agreement which is fair and implementable for all countries. 

Also each of us can make changes to our lifestyles, to save energy. Every little bit counts. - LHL

“Chasing Rainbows” is the English edition of a Chinese book 《追虹》 written by Choo Lian Liang. It was translated by her daughter, Sim Ann 沈颖.
 
Lian Liang is a veteran television producer and an accomplished writer. I’ve known her for 30 years, and Sim Ann too (not quite so long :) ). 

I read 《追虹》 cover to cover. It is a fascinating family history of four generations, beginning with Lian Liang’s great-grandfather in 1899. He failed the Imperial examinations, and sailed from Chaozhou to Singapore to find work. The family lived through the Japanese Occupation, the post-war anti-colonial struggle, and China’s Great Leap Forward. These tumultuous events profoundly affected their lives and fortunes. 
 
Many of us have similar histories of forebears who came to Singapore in search of a better life. “Chasing Rainbows” tells a vivid story of how the pioneers chased that rainbow and found the pot of gold. May it inspire our generation to be as intrepid, and to do even better. – LHL

Shocked and saddened to learn of the passing of Wong Meng Quang (“MQ”). I had just met him last week, at the Ho Rih Hwa Lecture. 
 
Meng Quang served Singapore with distinction. He headed EDB's Tokyo office, and was a consummate salesman for Singapore. He was fluent in English, Mandarin and Japanese, and landed major investments from Japan, including the Seiko watch factory.

MQ also played a key role in the decision not to pursue highly pollutive industries in Singapore. In the 1970s, foreign investors had proposed building an iron and steel complex on Pulau Ubin, but he advised against the plan. The project was reconsidered, and eventually called off. So in a sense, MQ saved Pulau Ubin.
 
Later MQ served as our Commercial Representative in Beijing. When we established formal diplomatic ties with China, he was in the team which negotiated the terms. He then continued as our Charge d’Affaires in Beijing. He accompanied me on my trips to China, and gave me good advice. 
 
My thoughts are with his family during this difficult time of mourning. - LHL 

(This pic was taken around 1990, when I visited China. / Photo courtesy of the late Mr Wong Meng Quang’s family.)

Am very concerned at the major disruption to train services last night. I had just recently visited the SMRT Bishan Depot, to see their maintenance operations and teams. So I went to the LTA Ops Centre this afternoon, to be briefed on the situation.

We are still trying to find out the cause of the problem. LTA and SMRT staff and engineers worked through the night checking trains, tracks and cables. Today fortunately trains ran without a glitch, so far. But because we have not identified the root cause of the power trips, we are still very worried that the problem may recur.

Hope we identify and resolve the faults quickly, to prevent further inconvenience to commuters. – LHL

Economy, Population, and Identity. Three critical challenges over the next 10, 25, and 50 years respectively. I spoke about them at the Ho Rih Hwa Leadership in Asia Public Lecture last night. 

For the economy, government agencies are working to create jobs, and SkillsFuture will help citizens become more resilient and adaptable. 

For population, we are managing immigration, promoting active aging, and most importantly, encouraging more Singaporeans to get married and start families! 

To forge national identity, we are nurturing shared values and experiences in our schools, NS and HDB towns. 

Some crucial shared experiences cannot be contrived - the passing of Mr Lee Kuan Yew, the tragic loss of young lives on Mount Kinabalu, and the triumph of the SEA Games. These times truly teach us what being Singaporean means.

After my speech, I answered some questions. My thanks to Mr Ho Kwon Ping for moderating the dialogue and to Singapore Management University for inviting me to this event.

Deeply saddened by the passing of Mr Chia Chwee Leong, at the ripe old age of 93. He and my father knew each other for more than 75 years. Their friendship survived the Japanese Occupation, Singapore’s independence, marriages, children, grandchildren and widowerhood.

Mr Chia first met my father in 1939 as students in RI and Raffles College. They lost touch when my father went to England to study, but after he came back, he looked up his old friend and they picked up where they last left off.

For 40 years, my parents would visit Mr Chia’s family at Chinese New Year. They did this every year until 2010, the year my mother passed away.

Mr Chia attended the wakes of both my mother and father. I am glad that my father had such a loyal and true friend. My deepest condolences to his children and loved ones on their loss. - LHL

We have maintained a clean and non-corrupt system in Singapore for half a century because we have zero tolerance for corruption. When we discover wrongdoing, we do not hesitate to act. We will not allow any cover up, even when it is awkward or embarrassing for the Government. 

Perhaps not many of you remember Phey Yew Kok. He was a PAP MP and senior union leader. In 1979, he was charged with criminal breach of trust and misuse of union funds. The following year he absconded while on bail, and became a fugitive from justice. 

Two days ago, Phey turned himself in at our Embassy in Bangkok, and today he returned to Singapore. Phey was charged in court this afternoon, and the law will have to take its course. – LHL

We read about the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) cases in the Middle East, and recently a major outbreak in South Korea. 

Sooner or later, we will have a MERS case in Singapore. We must be ready.
 
I visited Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) this morning. I wanted to be sure that the medical team and facilities are well drilled and ready. 
 
It's not just the medical team. The public too must be psychologically prepared, so that we won’t panic.

So if you have travelled recently and feel unwell, please see your doctor. Please tell him where you have been, especially if it was to the Middle East or South Korea. 

If we have a MERS case here, please stay calm, listen to advice from the govt, but otherwise go about your daily lives normally. Let’s take care of each other. – LHL

Am very sad to learn that 8 bodies recovered from Mount Kinabalu have been identified as 1 teacher and 6 students from Tanjong Katong Primary School, plus an adventure guide who accompanied them. Our hearts go out to their families, and to the TKPS community.
 
Our officers are in Kota Kinabalu helping and supporting the families. We are arranging to bring them home as soon as possible.
 
Even while we grieve for those who perished, we are thankful that others survived the earthquake and have come home safely.
 
I thank all who are working tirelessly in the rescue and recovery efforts – the Malaysian authorities, the search and rescue teams and hospital staff in KK, and all our officers in KK and Singapore.

I have declared tomorrow, 8 June, a Day of National Remembrance. State flags on all Government buildings will be flown at half-mast. One minute of silence will be observed at the beginning of the day at all SEA Games venues.
 
As we grieve over the loss of these young lives, we also take heart at their striving to stretch their limits and take on new challenges. May this tragic incident strengthen our sense of togetherness, and our resolve to overcome adversity and prevail as one united Singapore. - LHL 
 
#SabahQuake

My deepest condolences to all who lost loved ones in the Sabah earthquake. May you find the strength to recover from this dark hour. We are all with you. I have been following the situation in Sabah closely. 

Minister Heng Swee Keat has gone to Tanjong Katong Primary to meet parents of the 8 students and 2 teachers who have not been accounted for. 

We are arranging to fly these parents to Kota Kinabalu in the morning. Our consular staff are in KK already. We are also sending a medical team and liaison officers over, and will work with the Malaysian authorities to give them all the help they need. 

A team of counsellors are supporting the families. I know how anxious and distressed they must be. My heart goes out to them. They are in our thoughts and prayers. – LHL

An earthquake struck Sabah, Malaysia this morning. We have contacted most Singaporeans who are there, and are glad they are safe. 
 
However, several are still out of contact, including 8 students and 2 teachers from Tanjong Katong Primary School, on Mount Kinabalu on an overseas learning journey. We are doing all we can to reach them and I really hope they are alright.
 
This afternoon, we contacted our Malaysian counterparts to offer our support and help. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has also despatched a Crisis Response Team to Sabah to help Singaporeans there.  
 
My thoughts are with those affected by the earthquake, and their families. – LHL

The native Oriental Pied Hornbill was once extinct in Singapore. Thanks to a pair which returned to Ubin in 1994 and a successful breeding programme, there are now many birds on Pulau Ubin and at Sungei Buloh.

There are a few hornbills at the Istana grounds as well. Sada is one of them. He was introduced to the Istana in 2008 with his mate. The two have since produced 8 chicks.

Hornbills are loyal and devoted to their partners. When breeding, the female seals herself inside the nest for 3 months, and depends on the male to bring food for her and their chicks.

If you watch the SEA GAMES 2015 opening ceremony tomorrow, you may spot a hornbill taking part in the show. :) – LHL

Celebrated the 10th anniversary of the People's Action Party Policy Forum (PPF) last night.

At my dialogue after dinner, I was asked how the PAP could stay relevant to Singaporeans. I answered that (1) we should continue to serve the people; (2) we should debate policies and contribute ideas, as the PPF is doing; and (3) we should provide dedicated, capable leadership for the nation.

PPF’s first Advisor Heng Swee Keat spoke about forging a generation of new pioneers for Singapore. Our challenges today are different. But the spirit of our founding fathers – their sense of togetherness, toughness and ability to turn weaknesses into strengths – will take Singapore forward beyond SG50. - LHL

In a multi-religious society, from time to time religious issues overlap with social and moral questions, such as LGBT issues or income inequality. 

Achieving consensus requires much effort. The Government must always be watchful, prudent and hands-on to protect our religious harmony. Religious leaders play an important role too. 

Imam Habib Syed Hassan Al-Attas (shaking hands) is a veteran member of the Inter-Religious Organisation, Singapore (IRO). He set up an inter-faith museum at the Ba'alwie Mosque to promote peace and understanding between people of different faiths. After 9/11, at his initiative, 100 Muslim organisations issued a joint statement rejecting terrorism and explaining the true position of Islam. 

Last night, at the IRO’s 66th anniversary dinner at the Istana, President Dr Tony Tan presented Habib Hassan with the IRO Award for his outstanding work promoting inter-faith harmony.

I told the Founders Forum two weeks ago that the last computer program I wrote was a Sudoku solver, written in C++ several years ago (http://bit.ly/1DMK5Zk). Someone asked me for it. Here is the source code, the exe file, and a sample printout - http://bit.ly/1zAXbua

The program is pretty basic: it runs at the command prompt, in a DOS window. Type in the data line by line (e.g. 1-3-8---6), then the solver will print out the solution (or all the solutions if there are several), the number of steps the program took searching for the solution, plus some search statistics.

For techies: the program does a backtrack search, choosing the next cell to guess which minimises the fanout.

Here’s a question for those reading the source code: if x is an (binary) integer, what does (x & -x) compute?

Hope you have fun playing with this. Please tell me if you find any bugs! – LHL

#SmartNation

===========

Answer: As several of you noted, (x & –x) returns the least significant ‘1’ bit of x, i.e. the highest power of two that divides x. This assumes two’s complement notation for negative numbers, as some of you also pointed out. e.g. if x=12 (binary 1100), then (x & -x) = 4 (binary 100). I didn’t invent this; it is an old programming trick. :)

===========

Update: A few people suggested that I add a licence to the code. Have added it in the Google Drive folder.

Saddened by the passing of Goh Yong Hong. He was our longest serving Commissioner of Police. 

When Hotel New World collapsed, Yong Hong took charge of rescue efforts by Police and Civil Defence personnel.

He implemented community policing – the Neighbourhood Police Posts, the Neighbourhood Watch Scheme, and the National Crime Prevention Council. He emphasised crime prevention rather than reactive policing, and built strong partnerships with the community. It is his most enduring legacy, much admired by other police forces. 

My condolences to his family. – LHL

Since my father’s passing, there have been many suggestions on how to remember and honour him. I spoke in Parliament about these today. (http://bit.ly/1GD65JO)
 
Some MPs shared their views too. Ms Chia Yong Yong felt that rather than spending time debating memorials, we should think about how we can ensure that his ideals and values carry on through the generations.    
 
I agree with Yong Yong. The ideals and the way we live our lives are more important than any physical thing we build. Yet a physical symbol is also helpful to focus our minds, if we can build something filled with meaning.
 
The memorial we decide upon should reflect and strengthen our sense of what it means to be a Singaporean, why Singapore is worth striving and fighting for, and how we can continue to build a harmonious and successful Singapore for future generations.
 
You can watch my statement and replies to questions here: http://bit.ly/1aJc6ae
 
- LHL

என் அப்பாவின் இறுதிச் சடங்கில் நீங்கள் செலுத்திய அஞ்சலிகளைக் கண்டு நான் நெகிழ்ந்துவிட்டேன். குறிப்பாக, முத்துக்குமாரசாமி என் மீது ஒரு தாக்கத்தை ஏற்படுத்திச் சென்றார். குமார் தன் வாழ்க்கையை ஒரு நாட்சம்பள ஊழியராகத் தொடங்கி, தன்னை மேம்படுத்திக்கொண்டு, நாட்சம்பள ஊழியர் சங்கத்தின் தலைவராகவும் என்டியுசி மத்திய குழுவின் ஓர் உறுப்பினராகவும் உயர்ந்தார்.

குமார் போன்றவர்கள் மேம்பட்ட வாழ்வும் எதிர்காலமும் பெறவேண்டும் என்பதற்காக, தொழிற்சங்கங்களுடன் இணைந்து பணியாற்றியதன் மூலம் என் அப்பா அரசியலுக்குள் நுழைந்தார். சிங்கப்பூர் ஒரு நீண்ட வழி வந்துள்ளது, ஆனாலும் நாம் நம் வேர்களையோ அடையாளத்தையோ மறந்துவிடவில்லை.

அப்பாவின் இறுதிச் சடங்கில் குமார் பேசியதை மிக முக்கியமானதாகக் கருதுகிறேன். அவர் தன் இதயத்திலிருந்து பேசினார். அப்பா தனக்கு எவ்வளவு முக்கியமானவர் என்று தன் மனத்தில் உள்ளதை வெளிப்படையாய் பகிர்ந்துகொண்டார். அவர் தமிழில் பேசியதை ஆங்கில மொழிபெயர்ப்பு செய்யும்படி நான் கேட்டுக்கொண்டேன். அது இங்கே உள்ளது.

– லீ சியன் லூங்

Visited Mr Bernard Chen’s wake this evening. 

Bernard contributed to Singapore in many roles – as a civil servant in EDB and MOF, as a Minister of State (in Mindef), as an MP (for Radin Mas and later Clementi in West Coast GRC), and in the private sector. Being a grounded, hardworking and humble man, he had friends from all walks of life.  

I first met Bernard nearly 40 years ago, when my father brought me along for a visit to Iran and Egypt. Bernard was in the delegation and we became friends. Later when I entered politics, Bernard as a senior MP was always supportive and generous with his advice. 

I was sorry to hear from ESM Goh Chok Tong in January that Bernard had cancer. When my father died a fortnight ago, Bernard wrote to me. I was moved. Despite his illness, Bernard made the effort to console me, and to explain that he was unable to pay his personal respects to Mr Lee because he was terminally ill. 

I replied to Bernard thanking him for all that he had done over the years. I said that we each have to make our journey through life, and live it so that when it is complete, we can say with good conscience that we have done our part.  Bernard had definitely done more than his fair share and contributed much to Singapore. I counted it my privilege to have been his colleague and friend all these years. 

Bernard was a staunch Catholic, so I ended my letter with the Latin blessing Dominus vobiscum – The Lord be with you. Rest in Peace, Bernard. – LHL

Making several Cabinet changes today. 

I am promoting Masagos Zulkifli to full Minister. He has performed well, both in his ministries and as an MP in Tampines. It is the first time we are having two Malay full ministers, which reflects the progress of the Malay community.

Other changes are because Chan Chun Sing is taking over as Secretary-General of NTUC from Lim Swee Say. So Swee Say goes to Manpower, and Tan Chuan-Jin goes to Social and Family Development. (Chun Sing also gives up his post of Second Minister in MINDEF, which Lui Tuck Yew will take over.) 

Swee Say has done a lot in NTUC: helping workers to upgrade themselves, finding them new jobs when they are retrenched, assuring them that they do not face globalisation and international competition alone. Chun Sing will have much work to do building on what Swee Say has done, but I am confident that he is up to the task.

These changes are part of continuing leadership renewal, to build a strong ‘A’ team for Singapore.

Was amazed to find this old telegram when sorting through my father’s things at home. My parents had kept it all these years! When I saw it, the old childhood memory flooded back.
 
The date was 26 September 1958. My father was still practising as a lawyer in Lee & Lee. He was in Sibu (Sarawak) doing some cases, and was expected home. He sent this telegram to Lee & Lee (whose telegraph address was KYLEGAL SINGAPORE). It read simply “ARRIVING TODAY BATTLESHIP = LEEKUANYEW”. 
 
My mother did not understand the message. Was my father coming home on a battleship? The Lee & Lee secretary called the British Naval Base at Sembawang to check if any battleship was arriving from Sarawak, but they knew nothing about it. 
 
My father did arrive home that day, but not by battleship. He explained that he wanted steam boat for dinner, but as “steam boat” was two words, and telegrams were charged by the word, he wrote “battleship” instead, to save words and money! Sadly, since we had not understood the message, we did not have steam boat for dinner that night. :) - LHL

By now, you have probably heard about my father’s red box. Minister Heng Swee Keat posted about it last week. The red box was a fixture of my father’s work routine. It is now on display at the National Museum of Singapore in his memorial exhibition.

Some of my father’s other personal items are there too. His barrister’s wig (of horsehair) from when he was admitted to the Bar. And a Rolex Oyster Perpetual watch given to him by the Singapore Union of Postal and Telecommunications Workers after he represented them in the famous postmen’s strike in 1952. 

I enjoyed my visit to the exhibition a few days ago. Was happy to hear that many of you went yesterday. The exhibition will be on until 26 April. – LHL

My father used to write a column in Forbes magazine. This Forbes piece assessing his legacy sees the Singapore approach as an alternative to the welfare state that has worked. 

We rely on free market competition, yet every citizen is assured of good education, healthcare, housing, and retirement. We all have to work hard and save for ourselves and our families, but nobody is left to fend for ourselves alone. 

The Government creates conditions for a vibrant economy and good jobs. It builds effective, affordable social safety nets. But it avoids mortgaging our future, and burdening our children’s generation with debts.

We are strengthening our social safety nets, with MediShield Life, Silver Support, etc. But let’s not forget we are not scrapping a bad system, but improving a good one. - LHL

Thanks to NParks for naming a new orchid in honour of my father. 
 
Transforming Singapore into a Garden City was an enduring passion of my father’s. He did the first tree planting campaign in 1963. He formed NParks (originally the Parks and Recreation Department) to be a dedicated, specialised agency to realise the vision of a City in a Garden. The result is beautiful parks for all to enjoy.
 
The Aranda Lee Kuan Yew orchid hybrid (left) was chosen by NParks officers who staffed my father when he visited the Singapore Botanic Gardens, and knew what he liked. This hybrid is vigorous and robust. It also matches an earlier hybrid - in colour, form, stature and lineage - that was named after my mother, Vanda Kwa Geok Choo (right).
 
The new orchid will be displayed in Parliament House from Wednesday to Sunday. Those wishing to pay respects can visit from 10am to 8pm from tomorrow until Saturday. – LHL

Can the CPF help us to save enough for our retirement? The answer is Yes. How? Through the magic of compound interest. The 5% compounding rate on CPF Special Account contributions, over a working lifetime, means that by the time you retire, you will have three times as much in the Special Account as you have put in over the years. 

Minister Tan Chuan-Jin explained this in Parliament today. Listen to him do the sums for Ben, a young polytechnic graduate just getting married and starting to work. - LHL

“Never take our peace for granted. A strong deterrence is Singapore’s best defence.” – A timely reminder from Minister Ng Eng Hen at yesterday’s Committee of Supply debate. 

Eng Hen told the story of Lithuania, a small Baltic state close to Russia. In 2009, Lithuania ended military conscription (their form of NS). It had joined NATO, and assumed that its neighbourhood was peaceful. But after seeing Russia annex the Crimea and the war in Ukraine, Lithuania has now re-introduced conscription to build up its armed forces. 

When it comes to defence, we must never let down our guard. As Eng Hen said, by the time danger is upon us, it will be too little and too late to build up a defence.

The price of freedom is eternal vigilance. I salute all our SAF servicemen, who let us sleep peacefully at night.

Here’s an excerpt of Eng Hen’s speech. - LHL

In the Budget debate yesterday, NTUC Secretary-General Lim Swee Say made an interesting comment. Some employers told him Singapore has become too expensive to do business. 

Swee Say replied that businesses should not keep “chasing after sunsets, keep going for lower-cost locations”. 

Instead, businesses should “chase sunrises” and embrace the future, by exploring opportunities such as 3D printing, robotisation and digitisation of services. 

That’s why we are investing in our people, with new ideas like SkillsFuture Credits, to help Singaporeans pick up new skills and be ready for future challenges.

The Budget debate began yesterday. NMP Chia Yong Yong made an excellent speech about the CPF. I was not in the chamber to hear her, but watched it later on YouTube. 

Yong Yong cast the question in a broader perspective: whether it is right to think of the CPF as “our money”, to be spent solely as we choose. She explained how choice always comes with responsibility, and benefits always carry obligations. When we exercise personal choice (e.g. by spending our CPF savings early), there is a price to be paid (e.g. we may not have enough to support ourselves in old age), and that price should not be paid by someone else (e.g. other taxpayers).

Yong Yong had asked me earlier whether we had settled the CPF policy, and if so was it worth her while to speak. I said we had worked out the main changes, but strongly encouraged her to express her view and contribute to the public debate. I am glad that she did, and to such good effect.

Here’s an excerpt of her speech. You can view her full speech at: http://bit.ly/1aL3Tmh

- LHL

Do you see White and Gold, or do you see Blue and Black? This is the hot question on the internet right now.

But unlike some other internet crazes, this one has a scientific point. We think of the colour of things as being something fixed, a property of the thing. But in fact what colour we see depends on the context in which we see the thing, and on how our brains process the light which enters our eyes. So different people will sometimes see the same thing as having different colours.

Read this interesting piece on the science behind all this. - LHL

P.S. Personally, I see White and Gold. :)

2015年李显龙总理新春献词

“家”

农历新年是阖家共庆的佳节。在这喜庆节日，大家能深切体会到家的温馨。家中晚辈会向长辈拜年表达感激之意，并献上祝福，大人则会给晚辈发红包或压岁钱以示关爱，一家人开心庆团圆，沉浸在简单的幸福中。

正因为这个节日背后的深刻意义，即使我们工作忙碌、正在远行或是人在他乡，无法与家人一起吃团圆饭，我们也要尽力设法与家人保持联系。在这华人一年之中最重要的节日，我们不妨花点时间思考，生命中最重要，最珍贵的东西究竟是什么？家，对你而言又有着怎样的意义？

政府正竭尽所能协助国人建立温馨和乐，同时凝聚力强的家庭。我们通过“结婚与生育配套”，鼓励已婚夫妇生儿育女，并为家长们提供可负担得起的托儿和学前教育服务。我们希望今年新加坡会迎来很多金禧宝宝！为了鼓励多代家庭同住一个屋檐下，在生活中互相扶持，我们推出了三代同堂家庭组屋单位。我们也通过具有针对性的住屋津贴，鼓励年轻夫妇住靠近父母。另外，我们也透过建国一代配套、乐龄补贴计划和终身健保计划，来协助需照顾年长父母的子女减轻负担。

除了我们的家人和亲属，我们也应该加强新加坡这个大家庭的凝聚力。国人应该互相照顾，并向社会上的不幸人士和弱势群体伸出援手。我们正努力加强社会安全网，这包括协助低收入家庭拥有自己的房子。另外，今年底终身健保计划推行后，国人在面对庞大医院帐单时将不必担心付不起医药费。政府也检讨了公积金终身入息计划，协助各个家庭更好地规划退休生活。我们也扩大了就业补助计划，为低收入工友和他们的家人提供更多的支持。政府和社会人士将为需要援助的国人承担更多风险，让这些人士能更安心生活。我们会齐心协力，确保这些人不被抛在后头。

这些政策不是要取代家庭扮演的角色，而是为了协助维系家庭的向心力。我们不希望看到家庭关系变得薄弱；在其他一些社会，由于政府为家庭承担起更多责任，反而削弱了家庭关系。我们绝不能让这种情况发生在新加坡——不论是个别的小家庭乃至我们的新加坡大家庭。

凝聚力强的家庭是我国社会的基石。家庭成员之间互相照顾、互相影响、同甘共苦。家，激励我们向上向善，为自己也为家人谋取幸福。不论我们健康或病弱，不论我们处在顺境或逆境，我们的家会一直守护着我们，关心着我们。

单凭慷慨的社会政策或津贴，并不能打造幸福美满的家庭。家，不仅仅是我们和亲人之间关系的代名词，它更深层的意义在于我们如何维系亲情。因此，让我们用心经营我们的家：多抽空陪伴家人、教育孩子、尊敬和照顾年长的父母，以及积极帮助身边的人。

只要我们各尽本分，新加坡必将继续昌盛繁荣，不仅是取得经济上的繁荣，也能在这个多元社会，共筑一个和乐融融，和谐温馨的大家庭。。

最后，祝大家新年快乐！- 李显龙

Chinese New Year Message 2015

“Our Family”

Chinese New Year is a time to celebrate with our families. It is a time to reflect on the blessings of having a family – to thank our elders for what they have done for us, to appreciate our spouses, to shower love on our children. It is a time to enjoy the simple goodness of family.   

So even if we may be busy, travelling or living in far flung lands, unable to come together physically for the New Year reunion, let us make the effort to connect with one another. On this most important festival in the lunar calendar, let us pause and remind ourselves of what truly matters in life, of what it means to belong to a family.   

The Government is doing all it can to help people build strong families. We are encouraging couples to have more children. The Marriage and Parenthood Package will support them, as will more affordable childcare and pre-schools. This year, we look forward to celebrating the birth of many Jubilee babies. We are encouraging three-generation families to stay close-knit, and making it easier for young couples setting up home to live close to their parents, through targeted housing grants. The Pioneer Generation Package, Silver Support and MediShield Life will lighten the burden on families taking care of elderly parents.  

Beyond our immediate family and relatives, we should also strengthen our larger national family. Singaporeans need to take care of one another, and especially of fellow citizens who are vulnerable or less fortunate.  We are strengthening our social safety nets. We have made it easier for low-income families to own their homes, introduced MediShield Life to give more protection against large hospital bills, reviewed CPF Life to help families better prepare for retirement, and expanded Workfare to support low-income workers and their families. The state and the community are bearing more risk on behalf of individuals, to give those who need help more peace of mind.  We are all in this together.  

We are doing all this to help our families stay together, not to supplant the role that families play. Our family ties must not weaken, unlike what we have seen in other societies where the state has taken on more responsibility. We must not let this happen in Singapore – either to our individual families, or to our larger national family. 

Strong families are the bedrock of our society. Family members not only take care of each other. They laugh and cry together.  Every member is shaped by every other. Our families inspire us to be better, not just for ourselves but for each other. Our families are always there for us, in sickness and in health, for better or for worse.

Generous social policies and grants by themselves do not grow strong or happy families. A family is not just about whom we are related to, but how we relate to each other. Therefore, let us make the effort to build strong families – to spend time with each other, nurture our children, respect and care for our elderly parents, and through our deeds help those in greater need. 
 
If each of us plays our part, Singapore will continue to prosper and do well, not just economically, but as a harmonious and cohesive national family, diverse yet one. 

Happy Chinese New Year! – LHL

STATEMENT FROM THE PRIME MINISTER’S OFFICE

Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has been diagnosed with prostate cancer, and will undergo surgery to remove his prostate gland on Monday 16 February 2015. The robot-assisted keyhole prostatectomy will be carried out by Prof Christopher Cheng, the lead Urologist at the Singapore General Hospital (SGH).
 
In January, Mr Lee had undergone an MRI of the prostate which showed suspicious lesions. A subsequent biopsy found that one out of 38 samples contained cancer cells. 
 
Mr Lee decided on the surgical treatment option on the advice of a panel of doctors led by Prof Cheng, and is expected to recover fully. 
 
Data from Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Centre show that patients with similar medical profile and treatment have a cancer specific survival rate of 99% at 15 years.
 
Mr Lee will be on medical leave for one week. During this period, Mr Teo Chee Hean, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs, and Coordinating Minister for National Security, will be Acting Prime Minister.

PRIME MINISTER’S OFFICE 
15 FEBRUARY 2015

Paid my respects to the late Dr Koh Lip Lin at his wake last night. He served as the MP for Nee Soon (1979-1988) and Nee Soon South (1988-1996) until it was absorbed into Ang Mo Kio GRC.
 
Dr Koh was one of our education pioneers. He was the first Dean of Science at NUS, and before that the Head of Department of Chemistry and Dean of Science at Nanyang University (Nantah).
 
As MP, Dr Koh saw Nee Soon transform from a rural area into an HDB new town. He helped new residents to settle in, tackled the many teething problems like public transport and defects in the new HDB flats, and made sure their needs were looked after. 
 
He was one of the Chinese educated MPs who kept us close to the Chinese ground. Others like him were Yeo Toon Chia, Ho Kah Leong, and Chng Jit Koon. Many were Nantah graduates, like Dr Koh. One difficult decision they had to make was to support the reforms in the late 1970s that merged Nantah with NUS, and led eventually to the formation of NTU. 
 
Today we no longer have “Chinese educated” MPs, but many MPs speak Mandarin as a result of our bilingual policy. Our education system has progressed, and so has Singapore, thanks to Dr Koh and his generation.
 
My deepest condolences to his wife and family. – LHL
 
昨晚慰问了前议员高立人博士的家人。高博士曾担任义顺选区(1979-1988年) 和义顺南选区 (1988-1996年) 的国会议员，直到它被纳入宏茂桥集选区为止。
 
高博士是我国教育界的先驱，是新加坡国立大学(国大) 理学院的首任院长。之前曾担任南洋大学（南大）化学系主任及理学院院长。
 
当年的义顺是农村、有园林。在高博士的领导下，逐渐把它发展成崭新的组屋区。刚迁入新社区的居民面对不少困难，公共交通不足，新的房屋有缺陷等等。高博士很仔细的帮助这些居民，解决生活上的不便。
 
高博士自己是受华文教育的。像他出自华校的议员包括楊敦清、何家良、庄日昆。很多跟高博士一样，也是南大毕业生。当时，这群南大议员做出了重大的决定，很不容易，因为他们选择了支持教育改革，把南大与新大合并，多年后又改组，最后成立了南洋理工大学。
 
现在，我们已经没有所谓的受华文教育的议员，不过施行双语政策后，多位议员都能讲流利的英语和华语。
 
我们的教育制度改善了，新加坡也进步了。这些都是高博士和他那一代努力的成果，感谢他们为我们的付出。
 
这里向他的妻子和家人表示我最深切的哀悼。 - 李显龙

Our healthcare system has achieved good outcomes – low infant mortality, high life expectancy, good treatment for major diseases like cancer. However, as our people get older, demand for healthcare is rising. 

Disease patterns change too. Diseases of ageing (dementia, hypertension) and affluence (diabetes) are now more common than diseases of poverty (tuberculosis). 

At MOH's Universal Health Coverage Ministerial Meeting this morning, I talked about key shifts to keep our system up to date. e.g. we are providing more support for outpatient treatment with the CHAS scheme. 

We are also moving to MediShield Life, a universal and compulsory medical insurance scheme that covers everybody, regardless of age or pre-existing conditions.

Bilahari Kausikan, our Ambassador-at-Large, recently spoke on why Singapore, as a small state in Southeast Asia, has to be successful, and indeed extraordinary.

Because we do well, people take us seriously. As Bilahari put it, the most brilliant idea of a small country can be safely disregarded if inconvenient, but even foolish ideas of a big country must be taken seriously. 

My trip to Germany and Spain last week brought home to me how true this is. The ministers and business people I met were interested to know what we think, how we are tackling our problems, what opportunities we see around us. This is not at all normal for a small country. 

If we cease to be extraordinary, become normal, and stop being relevant to others, we will be sorry. - LHL

“A people who forget their history will perish.”

On Monday, IPS Director Janadas Devan gave a vivid account of the events leading up to Singapore’s independence on 9 August 1965. His conclusion struck a chord with me: that there was nothing inevitable about our separation from Malaysia. In fact our founding leaders had believed that Singapore could not possibly survive without a hinterland. The flow of events might well have ended up with “one country, two systems” and quite a different Singapore. 

Today we are in a much better position than in 1965, but we are still a vulnerable, small country in Southeast Asia. The dangers we avoided long ago are not permanently gone, but remain potential possibilities. If we forget our history, they may come back, and we will have to relearn painful lessons. 

Janadas was speaking at the Singapore Perspectives conference. Read his speech at http://bit.ly/1Lhqbd7. - LHL

I visited this plaque at the Esplanade Walk during the Christmas holidays. It marks the struggle against the Communist Party of Malaya (CPM). 

The CPM waged a violent, armed campaign for four decades. They killed many civilians and security personnel in their effort to install a Communist regime in Singapore and Malaya. Had they succeeded, the Esplanade would hardly look like this today.

Today, some revisionists and former CPM members and supporters still dispute these historical facts. Sam Tan addressed their assertions in a letter. You can read about it here: http://bit.ly/1ATO8S5 and http://bit.ly/1ucFaub

The deniers disrespect the memory of those honoured by this marker, who fought to keep Singapore a free nation. To them we owe our present security and success. - LHL

Spoke to public servants today about the importance of maintaining high standards of integrity, i.e. zero corruption. 
 
Singaporeans trust the public service to act with integrity, and always in the public interest. We have a clean system and many exemplary officers, but we cannot let down our guard.
 
We are reviewing the Prevention of Corruption Act, and building up CPIB. We are also setting up a One-Stop Corruption Reporting Centre so that members of public can send their complaints discreetly and conveniently. You can view my full speech here: http://bit.ly/1AaFAmP
 
- LHL
 
(PMO Video by Alex Qiu and Chiez How)

A major reason we have achieved so much in 50 years is that we have a clean, zealous and well-qualified Public Service which upholds high standards of integrity.

Singapore Civil Defence Force’s Sergeant Samuel Anandaraj Anthonyraj (top photo) came across a traffic accident at Serangoon Road, found the driver drunk, and stopped him from fleeing the scene. The driver offered him $1,000 not to tell the police. But he rejected the bribe, told the police, and the offender was subsequently jailed. 

Sgt Goh Week Kian and Sgt Tan Kai Siang from the Singapore Police Force's Criminal Investigation Department (flanking SGT Samuel) were also offered bribes. On a patrol in Geylang, they came across a woman suspected of vice activities. When she tried to bribe them, they arrested her both for the vice activity and for attempting to bribe police officers. 

Inspector Sayri Bin Mohamed Salleh from the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore - MPA (bottom photo) boarded a ship that was illegally degassing its storage tanks within port limits. The ship master told him he plied routes in Asia, and was able to settle these things in other Asian ports. But Inspector Sayri told him: “That is in other countries. In Singapore, we don’t practise that.”

This is the high standard we expect of our public officers. I spoke to public officers today about the importance of maintaining zero tolerance for corruption, strengthening our procedures and systems, and upholding integrity as a key value. You can view my speech here: http://bit.ly/1AaFAmP

– LHL

Dr Michael Fam was a rare and selfless individual, who contributed much to Singapore. He was a successful businessman who held leadership positions in companies like the F&N Group, Asia-Pacific Breweries, SIA, Temasek Holdings, OCBC Bank and SPH. But he also had the energy and commitment to do an enormous amount of public service.
 
In 1983, Singapore started building the MRT. Dr Fam chaired the Mass Rapid Transit Corporation (MRTC). The team completed the North-South and East-West Lines well within budget, two years ahead of schedule.
 
He was also chairman of the HDB from 1975 to 1983. Amidst a construction boom, contractors were reluctant to bid for HDB projects. But thanks to Dr Fam’s guidance, the HDB introduced pre-fabrication and mass production techniques, and got the housing programme back on track.
 
He sat on the Council of Presidential Advisers for many years and was also the founding chairman of the Nanyang Technological Institute, now NTU. 
 
I was saddened to hear of Dr Fam’s passing over the weekend. He embodied what it means to give back to society, to make lives better for all.  I extend my deepest condolences to his wife Dulcie and his family. - LHL

What problems will we run into as our population ages? One likely one: friction between the young and the old. This article describes this happening in Japan.

Japan's young are unhappy they have to pay for pensions and medical care for the old, at the expense of their own financial security. Meanwhile, the old bristle that the young are uncaring and ungrateful. 

Japan is renowned for its social cohesion and community mindedness. Yet the article tells of the elderly hogging seats on trains and cutting in line at supermarkets. 

It is a cautionary tale for Singapore. Like Japan, we are a rapidly ageing society. Last year 1 in 9 Singaporeans were 65 or older. This year, it has already grown to 1 in 8. (In Japan it is 1 in 4.) We must take care of each other and not let this happen here. - LHL

Ten years ago, on 26 Dec 2004, a huge earthquake off Sumatra triggered a deadly tsunami which crashed into coastlines around the Indian Ocean. 230,000 people died, and millions lost their homes.

I recall visiting Banda Aceh and Meulaboh in Indonesia days after the disaster. This was the closest land to the epicentre, and the worst hit. The SAF were already there, mounting our largest relief effort ever, to support our close neighbour. Our Home Team, NGOs, and individual Singaporeans were also helping.

I was overwhelmed by the extensive damage. But despite the trauma, grief and uncertainty, the survivors were determined to recover and not give up. A decade later, many of the destroyed areas are again bustling with life. The survivors have also rebuilt their lives. But we also remember those who have perished. 

The tsunami shows starkly how fragile and uncertain human life is, and how resilient and united we must be in the face of adversity. Natural calamities will happen again. We must be prepared for them, and work together to protect ourselves. – LHL

P.S. For more on the Indian Ocean Tsunami, see The Straits Times' e-book special.

Snapped this in the Mosque-Cathedral in Córdoba, Spain. It shows the Annunciation of the Virgin Mary, the Birth of Jesus, and the Adoration of the Magi. The scenes are on a huge gold monstrance (a receptacle for displaying the consecrated host) that stands 2.5 metres tall, and weighs 180kg! 
 
The Mosque-Cathedral has a fascinating history. Originally a church stood  there. When Muslim armies invaded Spain, they built a mosque on the foundations of the church. Over centuries, the Muslim rulers of Andalusia progressively expanded the mosque into a huge building that could hold 50,000 worshippers. After the Christians reconquered Córdoba in 1236, they re-consecrated the Great Mosque back to a cathedral. The influence of both religions is evident in the mix of Islamic motifs and Christian imagery. 

Today those wars are long past. Christians and Muslims live peacefully together in Córdoba. It is an apt message in the spirit of the season. – LHL

Here is an English translation of the Zaobao article:
 
By selecting a nearby neighbourhood secondary school, high scoring student saves on travelling time to spend more time on school work and family
 
When the PSLE results were released, 13-year-old Goh Wei Ling did not have to worry about which secondary school to apply for. This was not because her high score of 261 allowed her entry into any school of her choice, but because she had already made up her mind to apply for Evergreen Secondary School, a neighbourhood school that was next to her home.
 
This time last year, Wei Ling’s teachers and school mates thought she was “wasting” her chances but both she and her father, Mr Goh Poh Ling, a 68-year old taxi driver, thought it was a “worthwhile” choice.
 
Mr Goh said that his daughter could have gone to any school, but this one was the closest to home, and thus the most suitable. “If she went to a school further away, the journey there would have taken at least one hour, and a return trip would be two hours. That would have amounted to 730 hours in a year. Who would find the time to do their school work?” 
 
From her home in Woodlands Street 83, Wei Ling, who is now in Secondary One, takes just 5 minutes to walk to school everyday. The time she saves on traveling is spent on school work and with her family. “Lights out” is at 9.30pm and her family life is disciplined and healthy. 
 
Wei Ling said, “Rather than a school’s name or reputation, what matters more to my parents are good moral values. Every day, I spend most of my time with my family, and not on travelling. Ever since I was in Primary Four, I had already wanted to attend Evergreen and it is better than what I imagined.”
 
Wei Ling’s elder brother graduated from Evergreen, and was the school’s head prefect. He did well in his ‘O’ Levels, scoring eight A1s. Mr Goh related with pride how his children did not receive any tuition, as he could neither afford the fees nor the time. “For me, nothing is more important than a good upbringing, and the neighbourhood schools are not bad. If the child works hard, they can achieve good results, too. I am not from the Ministry of Education, but I believe that every school is a good school.” 
 
Brand name schools are attractive, but in the eyes of Mr Goh, what is more important is the sort of environment that suits the child. 
 
“If the child has the ability, they can go anywhere. Brand name schools are good, but the competition there is also strong. You may be first elsewhere, but be pushed down by the tougher environment. As parents, we should not let our children feel belittled. Instead, let them feel empowered. I will not insist that my children become doctors. Whatever she chooses to do, I will support as long as her heart is set on it.”
 
Wei Ling added that while many people may feel that neighbourhood schools are not as good, she disagrees. “I like Evergreen Secondary School very much and I have learnt a lot about life and being a better person here.”
 
Parent wants his child to be less tired
 
Siti Nurjaslina Bte Jeffry, 13, also performed well at last year’s PSLE. She chose to go to Fuhua Secondary School. Not only is it near her home, she was also attracted to their shooting CCA.
 
Even though she did not make it to the CCA, Siti was not disappointed as there were many other interesting CCAs she could choose from, and she now enjoys being part of the Malay Cultural Group. 
 
Siti’s father, Mr Jufri, a 44-year-old technician, said, “Life is already stressful in Singapore. I hope my children will not be too stressed. Her results could have gotten her into a brand name school, but she will be very tired. I don’t want her to be worn out. When you are under pressure, it will also be difficult to make friends and enjoy their friendship.”

I visited the Battle for Merger exhibition in October. This was the book of Mr Lee Kuan Yew’s radio talks in 1961, explaining what the fight against the Communists was about, and why Singapore needed Merger with Malaya. 

The Communist Party of Malaya (CPM) was a violent, illegal organisation. So it operated secretly, underground. But the Communists infiltrated open, legal organisations like trade unions, student associations and political parties. These supported the Communist cause, but denied that they themselves were Communist. Mr Lee exposed this Communist united front tactic.

I took these photos of a fascinating exhibit: a pair of original handwritten documents. One was a trade union document, signed 林清祥 Lim Chin Siong. He was the leader of the Barisan Sosialis, the main open front political party. The other was a Communist study cell document, signed 王明 Wang Ming. The handwriting was identical. In fact Wang Ming was Lim Chin Siong’s party name; Communist cadres took party names to conceal their real identities. So Lim Chin Siong was a Communist, and the Barisan Sosialis was Communist controlled.

This was more than 50 years ago. Many old Communist and pro-Communist activists have reconciled with their past, and become good citizens. But a few hard core ones still deny these historical facts. They don’t want to admit that they had fought on the wrong side, and that luckily for Singapore they lost. Some “revisionist” historians make this argument too. One motivation: cast doubt on the legitimacy of the PAP government, not just in the 1960s, but today.

The British have been declassifying documents from their archives in London, and making them available to the public. Also senior CPM leaders like Chin Peng, Eu Chooi Yip, Fong Chong Pik (aka the Plen) and others have published memoirs. Their first person accounts, like the British documents, confirm the extent of the Communist united front in Singapore, and leave no doubt that the Barisan was formed at the instigation of the CPM, and that Lim Chin Siong was a Communist cadre.

We have put together an account using evidence from the British archives as well as CPM sources, which confirm that Mr Lee Kuan Yew told the truth. Here it is, for your weekend reading. http://bit.ly/16BGul3 – LHL

One crucial fight Singapore went through on the road to nationhood was the fight against Communism, specifically the Communist Party of Malaya (CPM). 

The CPM sought to oust the governments of Malaya and Singapore, and replace them with a communist regime. It launched a campaign of violence and intimidation which lasted four decades. Fortunately the CPM failed, but 8,000 civilians and security officers lost their lives in the struggle. 

This morning Mr SR Nathan unveiled a marker at Esplanade Park, to honour and remember those who fought and sacrificed to keep Singapore a free nation, democratic and non-communist. Mr Nathan had personally witnessed Communist violence, and worked in the trade unions to overcome the influence of the pro-Communists in the unions. 

Today, the CPM is a distant memory. But we should never take our peace and harmony for granted. Do visit the marker if you can. – LHL

The People's Action Party held its Party Conference today to elect a new Central Executive Committee (CEC).

After that, we held a Rally to mark the Party’s 60th anniversary. For Singapore’s progress over these 60 years, we are forever indebted to our pioneers. Now it is our turn to make sure that our children can enjoy better lives than us. – LHL

The late Mr Ho See Beng was a washerwoman’s son, but that didn’t stop him from helping others. Amidst poor conditions and social unrest, See Beng toiled with other unionists in the NTUC to improve workers’ lives. They pressed employers and government to give workers better recognition and wages, and moved us away from adversarial industrial relations to harmonious tripartism. 

Glad that a book chronicling See Beng’s life and legacy has been published. His story reminds us that every Singaporean has a contribution to make to the Singapore story. May the book inspire young Singaporeans to emulate the tenacity, courage and conviction of our pioneers. - LHL

The CPF scheme has benefited thousands of members. We are improving it further, especially to help lower-income elderly people. We are also making the CPF more flexible, to give you more choices in retirement.

At the ND Rally, I set up an Advisory Panel to improve the CPF scheme. The Panel has been hard at work, holding focus group discussions. The public response has been good. 
 
For every change to the CPF system, there will be some trade-off. But we are doing our best to find a fair and sustainable system. The panel would like to hear from you. Please send them your views, at cpf_panel@mom.gov.sg.

To learn more about the CPF, please watch this video: http://bit.ly/1vlsS1s.

Came across this Economist article on the challenges the US pension system faces. As people are living longer, pension schemes are under pressure, including government Social Security. 

There are only three solutions: people must either live on less in retirement, work longer and retire later, or save more of their salary while working. 

This is exactly what a British pensions expert told me. Paul Myners was an advisor to GIC. He had done a study on pensions for the British government, and came to the same conclusion.

These are tough choices that countries – not just Singapore – are facing. 

- LHL

Extremist terrorism is a serious, long-term problem. Met community and religious leaders this morning to discuss the ISIS threat. We updated them on what has been happening, and they shared their views on what all of us can do to protect ourselves.

It will be tough to eradicate terrorism. But we will keep Singapore safe, if we work closely together. – LHL

Last night, the Lam Ann Associations held their 12th international gathering in Singapore. It was also the 88th Anniversary of the Singapore association. 

Lam Ann is a county in Fujian province, near Xiamen. During the Tang and Sung dynasties, it was the starting point of the maritime silk route. 

Many Hokkiens who came to Singapore were originally from Lam Ann. They include war hero Lim Bo Seng, philanthropist Lee Kong Chian and artist Tan Swie Hian. Lim Boh Seng’s father, Lim Loh, was the contractor who built the Victoria Memorial Hall (now the Victoria Concert Hall) a century ago. Their descendants continue to contribute to the community today. (Grace Fu is one of them, as are Denise Phua, Lee Bee Wah, and several other MPs.)

I wish the community many successful years ahead. – LHL

Came across this moving and inspiring story on Typhoon Haiyan. A year ago, Haiyan struck parts of Southeast Asia. But the Philippines was worst hit. 6,000 people died and millions were displaced. 
 
Today, the victims are rebuilding their lives, though many are still in temporary shelters or evacuation centres. But the Philippines people - like Lt Col Fermin Carangan and Miguel Rulona – are resilient, and I believe they will overcome this and rebuild. 
 
The Singapore Red Cross has completed 11 projects to restore healthcare, schools, safe and clean water and livelihoods to local communities in the Philippines. Another 9 projects are on track. They were funded by donations from Singaporeans and the government. Thanks to all who supported our efforts to help rebuild the Philippines. – LHL

Tourism in Singapore has come a long way. 50 years ago, We only had a handful of attractions - Haw Par Villa, the Botanic Gardens, and Mount Faber. Today we have Sentosa, Gardens by the Bay, the River Safari, and many more, enjoyed by both Singaporeans and tourists.

Last night, the Singapore Tourism Board celebrated its 50th anniversary, and recognised the front-line staff too - without them, none of this would be possible! 

But we must continue keeping Singapore special, always offering visitors something fresh. This is why we are revamping Mandai, developing new attractions like a new Bird Park, and also integrating the Zoo, Night Safari and River Safari into a nature-themed destination. 

We are making Singapore the best place to live, work and play. – LHL

Was saddened to read of the passing of COL (Ret) John Morrice.

John helped to build the SAF. He joined the Singapore Military Forces when Singapore was still a British colony. When Singapore left Malaysia, he decided to come back to Singapore. He trained the legendary first batch of officers to graduate from SAFTI, as their OC. Later, he commanded the 2nd Infantry Brigade, and became a mentor to generations of SAF officers.

After retirement, he was the President of the SAF Veterans’ League. 

I worked under John as a young SAF officer. When I joined the General Staff, he was one of the senior commanders we worked closely with. So I was happy to see him do this video for the Pioneer Generation Package.

Without John and his generation of officers, we would not have today’s SAF. My deepest condolences to Mrs Morrice and the family. - LHL

The Ebola outbreak in West and Central Africa is a very serious epidemic, worsened by inadequate medical facilities and government services. Many countries are pitching in to help these countries fight Ebola. Singapore is doing our part as well. 
 
We are donating US$150,000 to support the World Health Organisation (WHO) Ebola Response Roadmap. This is on top of the package of medicine, medical supplies and personal protective equipment which we contributed last month. 
 
In Singapore the risk is low, but being an air hub, we cannot rule out Ebola cases being imported. We have put in measures to deal properly with them. 
 
We will continue working closely with the United Nations and WHO to contribute to ongoing efforts to fight this epidemic. - LHL

Sri Thendayuthapani Temple on Tank Road (also called the Chettiar Temple, shown in pic) was gazetted as a National Monument on Monday. I recall fondly the temple’s annual processions that used to pass in front of my home at Oxley Road. They were great occasions for all the children in the neighbourhood.

The Chettiars were a community of traders, merchant bankers and moneylenders. Many Chettiars used to occupy kittangis (warehouse shops) near the temple, where they did their moneylending business sitting at low tables with wooden cash boxes.

See http://www.sttemple.com/information/about-chettiars.html to learn more about the Chettiars in Singapore. - LHL

Crab for lunch! Shell CEO Mr Ben van Beurden gave me this memento after I presented Shell with an Honorary Partner in Progress Award from EDB today. 
 
This is a new species (the Indopinnixa shellorum), discovered at St John’s Island in a marine biodiversity survey that Shell had funded. But relax – I am not really eating a real crab, this is just a 3D-printed model! :)
 
Shell’s business in Singapore goes back more than a century. Shell built our first oil storage installation on Pulau Bukom in 1891. Since then they have steadily invested here, and created many good jobs and career pathways for Singaporeans. Look forward to many more years of successful partnership together. – LHL

We have been worried for some time about people going to Syria and Iraq to join the extremist groups there. Quite a number come from our region. A few Singaporeans have done so too. Even Japanese have been caught up - a student from Hokkaido University is being questioned by the Japanese police about his plans to join ISIS. DPM Teo Chee Hean just answered a question in Parliament on this on Tuesday. I came across this BBC story about some Kosovans who went to become suicide bombers in Syria, and the anguish it caused their families. Hope it helps you understand why we take the threat so seriously. – LHL

I met Puan Noor Aishah, wife of our first President, at the National Day Rally. Was very happy to host her to lunch today. Her son, Imran, and his wife, Zarina, were in town. Imran and I used to play together as children, and he taught me how to ride a bicycle. We used to call him “Baba”. He is now a doctor, working in Brunei. We had a good time reminiscing about our childhood days, and catching up. – LHL

Saya bertemu Puan Noor Aishah, isteri Presiden Pertama kita di Rapat Umum Hari Kebangsaan lalu. Hari ini, saya gembira sekali kerana berpeluang menjamu beliau makan tengahari bersama anak beliau, Imran dan isterinya, Cik Zarina. Saya dan Imran rakan bermain semasa kami kecil dulu. Imranlah yang mengajar saya mengayuh basikal! Dulu kami menggelarnya "Baba". Kini beliau seorang doktor dan bertugas di Brunei. Kami saling bertukar khabar dan sempat singkap kisah-kisah zaman kami kanak-kanak dulu. – LHL

We all have to do our part to raise productivity. We launched the National Productivity Movement in the 80s. 30 years on, Teamy the Bee has retired, our workers are better-skilled, and the economy is more developed. But productivity is still crucial. 

The message in this old poster is still relevant. Employers need to make their operations more productive, while upgrading their workers’ skills. Workers need to make the effort to train and improve themselves, and contribute to improving work processes. The Government will support employers and workers with schemes and incentives. Together, we can raise our productivity, and improve lives for all.

- LHL

Congrats to Team Singapore on a job well done! 

We won 5 Golds, 6 Silvers and 13 Bronzes in this year’s Asian Games. It’s a great achievement for Singapore, but more importantly, the experience gained at the Games has enriched our 223 athletes, more than half of whom were debutants.

Selamat Hari Raya Aidiladha to all our Muslim friends!

This year, 680 pilgrims from Singapore joined millions of Muslims in one of the world’s largest annual pilgrimages. We appreciate the Saudi government’s efforts to ensure a safe pilgrimage, while they are upgrading the Holy Mosque in Mecca. Hope more Singaporeans can go on the hajj when the works are completed. 

Muslims also perform the korban (sacrifice) rites today to commemorate Prophet Ibrahim's act of submission to God. Read in Berita Harian that some 170 sheep died en route to Singapore. Glad that we still had enough livestock for the korban rites. My thanks to all the mosque staff and volunteers who have worked hard on the korban arrangements. – LHL

Selamat Hari Raya Aidiladha kepada semua umat Islam!

Tahun ini, seramai 680 jemaah Singapura menyertai jutaan jemaah lain menunaikan ibadah haji, antara perhimpunan terbesar dunia. Kami menghargai usaha kerajaan Saudi untuk memastikan jemaah haji kita dapat menunaikan ibadah haji dengan selamat di tengah-tengah kerja pembangunan dan naik taraf Masjidil Haram di Makkah. Semoga lebih ramai jemaah Singapura akan dapat menunaikan fardhu haji apabila kerja-kerja pembinaan di sana selesai.

Umat Islam juga melakukan ibadah korban hari ini untuk memperingati keteguhan iman Nabi Ibrahim. Saya terbaca di Berita Harian, bahawa ada sekitar 170 kambing yang terkorban dalam perjalanan ke sini. Mujur bekalan haiwan untuk disembelih mencukupi. Terima kasih kepada para kakitangan dan sukarelawan masjid atas kerja keras anda memastikan ibadah korban tahun ini berjalan lancar. – LHL
