It’s been years since I read to my own children, so I was a bit rusty reading a storybook for the kidsREAD programme this morning. I chose “Go to sleep, Gecko!”, a Balinese folktale retold by Margaret Read MacDonald. 
 
The kidsREAD programme has come a long way since I launched it with Yaacob Ibrahim 10 years ago. Our aim was a nation-wide reading programme to help children from poorer families learn to read. 

National Library Board, Singapore, The People's Association and the self-help groups have done very well. More than 27,000 children have read with us. Many volunteers, from 11 to 71, have taken part in the reading sessions. 

A big thank you to all of you for sharing the joy and benefits of reading with our little ones! - LHL

(PMO Video by Alex Qiu and Chiez How)

A decade ago, I spoke at the 50th anniversary of the National University of Singapore Society. Was honoured to be invited back to give another lecture, on Singapore in Transition, for their 60th anniversary last night.

I spoke on why we need to look outwards, balance good-heartedness and hard-headedness, and learn from the past to have confidence in our future. Read my speech here (http://bit.ly/1xLBgxS) and watch the video here (http://bit.ly/YXiOTK)

I also answered questions, which ranged from Occupy Central in Hong Kong to Singapore’s next generation of leaders.

Here’s a clip from last night’s dialogue session, on how we can ensure our kids are anchored in sound values. You can watch the rest at http://bit.ly/1vF938P - LHL

Devotees carrying an "emperor" on a sedan in the procession.

Congrats to Iskandar Jalil, who recently received the Japanese Foreign Minister's Commendation for promoting appreciation for pottery and Japanese ceramic art in Singapore.

One of Singapore’s best known artists, Pak Iskandar has raised ceramic art in Singapore to a high level. I have presented several of his unique pieces to other world leaders (most recently to Chinese Vice Premier Zhang Gaoli), and felt proud when they expressed appreciation for his artistry.

Pak Iskandar has also been generous in nurturing young artists. He has become a role model and inspiration to many.

I was sorry to read in Berita Harian recently that he has advanced prostate cancer, but was deeply moved by his will to live life to the fullest. I wish Pak Iskandar well. – LHL

Tahniah kepada Iskandar Jalil yang baru-baru ini menerima pujian Menteri Luar Jepun atas usahanya menyemai minat dan penghargaan terhadap seni tembikar dan seramik Jepun di Singapura.

Pak Iskandar adalah antara seniman tersohor negara dan telah memartabatkan seni seramik di Singapura. Saya pernah menghadiahkan para pemimpin dunia beberapa tembikarnya yang unik sebagai cenderahati (baru-baru ini kepada Naib Perdana Menteri China, Zhang Gaoli). Saya bangga apabila mereka menghargai kehalusan karya seninya.

Pak Iskandar juga bersifat murah hati dalam memupuk golongan seniman muda. Beliau adalah seorang tokoh yang menjadi sumber inspirasi kepada ramai.

Saya prihatin membaca laporan Berita Harian mengenai barah prostat tahap akhir yang dihadapinya tetapi saya amat tersentuh dengan azamnya yang kuat untuk terus menjalani kehidupan dengan sebaik mungkin. Sebagai rakan senegara, kita amat berbangga dengan pencapaian Pak Iskandar dan berterima kasih atas sumbangan murninya mengharumkan nama Singapura.

Salam sejahtera buat Pak Iskandar sekeluarga. – LHL

(Left: Photo by me, of Pak Iskandar’s work on display in the Istana; Right: Pak Iskandar at home, ST Photo © Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Reproduced with permission.)

At the National Day Rally, I talked about keeping our Asian cultures alive. I described how our Chinese community has developed our own local and unique Nanyang brand of culture, for example Xinyao, Singapore Chinese dance and even Chinese music with a local flavour.

I also mentioned the Singapore Chinese Culture Centre (SCCC) project. So I was happy to attend the Centre’s ground-breaking ceremony today. 

The SCCC will be a handsome 11-storey building next to the Singapore Conference Hall. It will promote both traditional and modern Chinese culture, and Singapore’s own unique Chinese culture. I look forward to its completion and the staging of many exciting events there. - LHL

在今年国庆群众大会的华语演讲里，我谈到了我们如何发展在新加坡独特的华族文化，南洋风。这些年来，我们就酝酿出了新谣，融合了中西式还有东南亚风味的新加坡华族舞蹈以及充满南洋色彩的华乐团。 

我也提到我们将成立新加坡华族文化中心。文化中心就选了今天这良辰吉日，举行了奠基仪式。 

华族文化中心将有新的设施，在那里能举行各式各样的文化艺术表演，会议及展览。华族文化中心除了推广传统和现代中华文化，也将提倡新加坡的华族文化。我拭目以待，竣工后的文化中心将是华族文化活动的新聚点，到中心观赏更精彩的节目和表演。- 李显龙

Did you know the Singapore Indian Chamber of Commerce & Industry is 90 this year? In this time, the chamber has helped many companies grow their businesses both here and abroad.

At the anniversary dinner last night, I was given an Indian chess set. Chess shares much of the intricate and dynamic nature of entrepreneurship. Like a good chess player, the entrepreneur has to see the big picture, anticipate challenges and adapt his strategies to win.

I presented the Singapore Indian Entrepreneurship Awards to three “master chess players”: Gopal Balakrishnan (provider of testing services for marine, oil, gas and construction industries), Dinesh Verma (rehabilitative healthcare products and physiotherapy service provider) and Ajit Aravind Prabhu (engineering service provider). May they inspire more budding entrepreneurs to chase their dreams! - LHL

My deepest condolences to Mrs Lim and family on the passing of Professor Arthur Lim.  

Arthur was a pioneer, visionary and giant in Singapore medicine. He founded our National Eye Centre, conceived the Singapore Eye Research Institute, and put Singapore medicine on the world map. 

Arthur mentored generations of eye surgeons and lit the lives of millions of people around the world. He trained more than 5,000 specialists in the 10 eye centres that he helped establish in China, restoring the vision of about one million cataract patients there.

His legacy will live on as we remember his life and his contributions. – LHL

[ST Photo © Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Reproduced with permission.]

After welcoming new Singaporeans in Cheng San yesterday afternoon, I presented 150 residents in Teck Ghee their Pioneer Generation Package Welcome Packs.

Teck Ghee is a mature estate and has many Pioneers. Like many other elderly Singaporeans, some of them worry about health and medical expenses, others about retirement funds, and some just about not burdening their children. I hope the benefits of the PG Package will ease their worries.

I was moved to see these elderly men and women, who had done so much for Singapore, now in the autumn of their lives, come together to receive their Packs and to be honoured. They looked happy, and with good reason.

For more information, please visit www.pioneers.sg, or call 1800-2222-888 (general enquiries) or 1800-650-6060 (healthcare enquiries). Our PG teams will also be visiting our Pioneers to explain the details personally.

Thank you again to all Pioneers, and I wish you good health and long life! - LHL

Making Singapore our best home goes beyond running it better or using technology more – it is also about making every corner of Singapore an outstanding environment.

PM announced that the Jurong Lake District would be next in Singapore’s continuing drive to transform the heartlands. Part of these plans includes the creation of the Jurong Lake Gardens, integrating the Chinese Gardens, the Japanese Gardens, and Jurong Lake Park. (Photo by LHL)

#ndrsg

HOME FOR ALL AGES: Ultimately, the aim is to make Singapore the best place to live, work and play, PM said. Though Singapore’s physical transformation is already remarkable, the Government will work to improve our living environment further. 

One way to do this is to get agencies to work more closely together, to sort out municipal issues. As such, we will set up a new Municipal Services Office. It will coordinate the work of all the front-line agencies (LTA, PUB, NParks, etc) so they can serve people better. Another way to serve people better is to use technology to make Singapore a Smart Nation. PM will find another opportunity to talk about our plans. 

#ndrsg

PM: Government will set up an advisory panel to study: 

a) how people can be allowed to take out part of their CPF  savings in a lump sum after the age of 65, subject to limits; 
b) how the Minimum Sum should be adjusted over time, so that members can continue to get an adequate basic retirement payout; 
c) how members can have more flexibility to invest their CPF savings; and
d) how CPF Life payouts can take account of cost of living adjustments.

The final Minimum Sum adjustment, scheduled for next year, will be $161,000 for those turning 55 from 1 July 2015. With a property pledge, you will only need $80,500 in cash.  

#ndrsg

CPF plus HDB have enabled a majority of the population to save enough for retirement, PM noted. However, a minority may not have enough. A new Silver Support scheme will be introduced to help low-income elderly Singaporeans. It will pay a bonus each year, starting from age 65, to help them with their living expenses and cost of living. More details will be announced at Budget next year.

(MCI Photo)

#ndrsg

PM: There are many ways to unlock the value of your house. You can rent out a room, or right-size and take advantage of the Silver Housing Bonus, or take advantage of the Lease Buyback Scheme. The Lease Buyback Scheme will be extended to 4-room flats, thus covering more than half of all flats in Singapore.

 #ndrsg

ASSURANCE IN RETIREMENT: 4 key points from PM’s speech -

1. CPF and home ownership go hand-in-hand in providing for your retirement. 
2. The current Minimum Sum is not too much.
3. If you own a house, you only need to set aside half of the Minimum Sum – or $77,500 – for those who turned 55 this July. 
4. You have many options to get money from your house.

(PMO Image)

总理华语群众大会演讲2014

总理说没有刻苦耐劳的建国一代，就没有今天的新加坡。 我们应该饮水思源，用一个恰当的方式，向建国一代表达我们的一份谢意。政府推出特别配套，希望能为建国前辈带来生活上的帮助。 
 
政府的另一大目标，是确保大家有足够的退休金，可以安享晚年。这个可以通过公积金制度和住屋政策两大政策来达到目的。总理说政府了解一些国人对公积金制度有一些见解，所以将调整公积金制度，使它更加完善，可以更好的帮助人民。总理说另一个能够保障国人晚年生活的政策就是居者有其屋政策。政府也会继续调整这些措施，尽量帮助国人利用房子来养老。总理将会在英语的演讲中进一步地解释这些政策。
 
总理也强调政府要让国人对未来充满信心和希望。无论国人处在哪一个起跑点，都有机会提升自己。在职场上一边工作，一边学习，也能出人头地。政府的教育目标，是要让人们按照自己的兴趣、专长和天赋，追求一个适合自己的学习道路，使自己的才华得到最充分的发挥。
 
要有好的生活，总理说，我们一定要有蓬勃的经济来进一步拓展国内和国际市场，特别是亚洲新兴的经济体，包括日益强盛的中国。政府会通过论坛促进新中企业交流，加深新加坡企业对中国的了解，促进新中两国创业者之间的合作。
 
总理说，新加坡华族，因为文化背景相近，以及具备双语能力，可以更容易融入中国社会。一直以来，政府也不遗余力支持民间组织，推广华族文化和母语教育。总理说，我们的宗乡会馆就做了很多工作，积极提倡文化和教育事业。政府会全力支持宗乡总会提出设立华族文化中心的构想。总理会在下个月为中心主持动土仪式。
 
华族文化中心所推广的文化，除了传统和现代中华文化，也将涵盖新加坡独特的华族文化。经过多年的酝酿，新加坡华族文化已经逐渐形成一种南洋风格。 
总理说，新加坡已经步入了第一世界，但是我们还没有发展到极限；我们还有无限发展的空间。我们需要的是先辈那种勇于开拓、积极进取的精神，新加坡才能攀上另一个高峰。
让我们朝着这个方向一起前进，共同努力。
 
#NDRsg

Rapat Hari Kebangsaan 2014 – Ucapan Bahasa Melayu 

Dalam ucapan Bahasa Melayunya, PM telah mengulangi penghargaannya kepada golongan Perintis Melayu.

Encik Lee menekankan bahawa warga Perintis Melayu sebenarnya ada pilihan (samada untuk menyertai Malaysia atau kekal di Singapura) apabila Singapura Merdeka. Tetapi mereka memilih untuk jatuh-bangun bersama Singapura sehingga negara ini mekar menjadi sebuah masyarakat berbilang kaum dan agama yang unik – yang bersatu padu dan harmoni. Beliau mengulangi penghargaannya kepada golongan Perintis Melayu kerana yakin dengan masa depan Singapura dan bertungkus-lumus dengan kaum lain, membangunkan Singapura.

Salah seorang tokoh Perintis Melayu cemerlang yang disebut PM ialah Encik Yusof Ishak, Presiden pertama Singapura. PM mengumumkan 3 bentuk penghargaan sebagai menjunjung budi dan pengorbanan Encik Yusof kepada Negara:

Pertama, sebuah masjid baru di Woodlands akan dinamakan “Masjid Yusof Ishak”.

Kedua, Institut Pengajian Asia Tenggara bakal dikenali sebagai “ISEAS – Institut Yusof Ishak”. 

Ketiga, NUS akan memulakan “Kerusi Profesor Yusof Ishak dalam Sains Sosial”. 

Dalam ucapannya, PM turut menarik perhatian tentang kemajuan besar yang dicatat masyarakat Melayu/Islam sepanjang 50 tahun lalu. Ini ketara melalui contoh-contoh individu Melayu/Islam yang berjaya saban tahun. 

PM juga menarik perhatian tentang penekanan pemerintah untuk menghargai setiap individu berdasarkan sumbangannya dan bukan hanya kelayakannya. PM mengumumkan pembentukan Jawatankuasa ASPIRE yang akan bantu rakyat menggilap potensi mereka melalui pembelajaran sepanjang hayat dan latihan kemahiran khususnya buat pelajar ITE dan politeknik. Ini agar setiap rakyat berpeluang untuk majukan diri dan perbaiki kehidupan mereka.

Menggulung ucapannya, PM yakin masyarakat Melayu/Islam akan mencatat kejayaan demi kejayaan jika mereka terus bersatu-padu. PM menyeru agar masyarakat Melayu/Islam menjunjung semangat golongan Perintis, perkukuh masyarakat berbilang kaum kita dan memperteguh komitmen untuk membentuk Singapura yang lebih baik buat semua.

In the last week, the armed conflict in Gaza has hotted up. Hundreds of people have been killed, mostly civilians, including many children and infants. The loss of innocent lives is tragic and painful. The Middle East is far away, but still we empathise with the pain and suffering of the Palestinian people, because of our common humanity.
 
Alas there is no easy solution. The Israel-Palestinian problem goes back almost a century. The distrust and enmity are mutual, and deep. Yet there is no future in this endless cycle of violence and retribution. 
 
Any lasting solution must begin with restraint and an end to violence, by both sides. I hope all parties will work together to stop this latest episode of violence. 
 
Let's keep the victims of the ongoing conflict in our thoughts and prayers. MUIS is collecting funds for humanitarian assistance to Gaza. Singaporeans have donated generously, and not only Muslims. I hope more concerned Singaporeans will continue showing support in this way. - LHL
 
Konflik bersenjata di Gaza semakin meruncing sepanjang seminggu ini. Ratusan nyawa terkorban, kebanyakannya orang awam termasuk ramai kanak-kanak dan bayi. Korban jiwa mereka yang tidak bersalah dalam jumlah yang besar ini, amat menyayat hati. Walaupun Timur Tengah begitu jauh, kita dapat rasakan kepahitan dan kesengsaraan yang ditanggung rakyat Palestin kerana ikatan kemanusian yang kita semua kongsi bersama.

Tiada huraian mudah. Masalah Israel-Palestin berakar umbi hampir seabad lamanya. Mereka saling tidak mempercayai dan permusuhan begitu mendalam. Lingkaran keganasan dan tindak balas yang tiada penghujung tidak menjanjikan masa depan yang baik untuk rakyat. 

Sebarang huraian jangka panjang mesti bermula dengan kedua-dua pihak menghentikan keganasan. Saya harap semua pihak bekerjasama untuk akhiri gelombang keganasan terbaru ini. 

Marilah kita sama-sama mendoakan kesejahteraan mangsa-mangsa konflik yang sedang berlaku ini. MUIS mengumpul dana bagi bantuan kemanusiaan untuk Gaza. Rakyat Singapura telah menyumbang dengan murah hati termasuk bukan Muslim. Saya harap rakyat Singapura yang prihatin akan terus memberi sokongan mereka melalui cara ini. - LHL

DPM Tharman Shanmugaratnam and Minister Tan Chuan-Jin made good speeches on the CPF in Parliament today.

DPM Tharman gave a full account of our CPF returns and investments. It was a comprehensive statement, but the main points are that our CPF monies are safe and earning good returns. Do click on the link below to watch DPM Tharman's replies, or read his speech at http://bit.ly/TPHBGL.

Chuan-Jin explained how the CPF Minimum Sum gives Singaporeans a steady stream of income in retirement. He dispelled some common misunderstandings about the Minimum Sum. e.g. did you know that if you own a house, you don’t need to set aside $155,000 - the full Minimum Sum – in cash, but only half - $77,500, and that you could cover the rest with a property pledge? You can watch Chuan-Jin by clicking on the playlist below, or read his speech at http://bit.ly/1owFDF5.

Our CPF system is sound, and has helped Singaporeans save for their old age. Many countries want to learn from us. But we are not resting on our laurels. We are improving our system to give all Singaporeans peace of mind in their silver years. - LHL

Mr Ee Boon Lee, a veteran journalist, passed away on Sunday. I paid respects at his wake last night after Mr Lim Kim Woon's wake. 
 
Boon Lee spent his life in the media industry. As a young reporter, he accompanied my father overseas, including an epic month-long journey in 1964 to Africa to explain Malaysia to influential African leaders, and another trip to Eastern Europe after Separation to brief them of Singapore’s independent, sovereign status.

He later ran NTUC News and edited the PAP publication Petir. He was a professional journalist, with a good feel for the ground and a knack for getting on with people.
 
I last met Boon Lee at the Pioneer Generation Tribute event in February this year. He was in good spirits; I did not even realise that he was already ill.
 
May Boon Lee rest in peace. – LHL 
 
(MCI Photo by Terence Tan)

Very saddened that my old principal, Mr Lim Kim Woon, has passed on. 
 
Mr Lim belonged to our pioneer generation of educators. He was the founding principal of National Junior College. My wife and I were his students in the first two batches. Like many others, we were inspired by his energy, enthusiasm, and concern for our well-being and moral upbringing. Mr Lim left a deep impression on us all, and we stayed in touch with him for decades.
 
I’m glad NJC has set up a “Lim Kim Woon Award”, for the student who best exemplifies NJC’s motto of “Service with Honour”. It is a fitting tribute to Mr Lim’s lifelong passion for serving the community with honour and integrity. 
 
Rest in peace, Mr Lim. - LHL

I circulated this article to my colleagues, to remind ourselves to be simple and direct when we communicate with the public. Whether it is an informal conversation, a speech, or a press statement, say what we mean. Avoid management speak or big words which will not impress anyone. Use simple language which people can understand.

On Facebook I always make my posts as simple and clear as possible. Even then from time to time after something has been posted I notice ways to say it better. Then I will change it, which is why you sometimes see that my posts have been edited after posting. (e.g. this one :))

Ministers and the govt have tried hard to be direct and clear in our comms, but once in a while we still fall short. Perhaps someone can set up a website which collects examples, and help us do better! 

– LHL

Came across this thoughtful piece by Andy Mukherjee over the weekend. It explains clearly the issues and trade-offs Singapore faces in building our ideal society, while ensuring that Singaporeans have jobs and economic opportunities to build better lives and a brighter future.
 
As the article points out, we do enjoy important advantages compared to other countries, but it will still not be easy. There are serious trade-offs, which we must be willing to acknowledge and address. If we just pretend that everything can be better, and no hard choices are necessary, we will get into trouble. Mukherjee calls this “please-all economics”, and expresses confidence that Singaporeans are too pragmatic to fall for it. We must make sure that he is right. – LHL

Last night, I attended the Reunion Dinner of the first three batches of the Reservist Officers’ Staff Course. The ROSC was started back in 1982 when I was serving in the SAF. Many of the graduands are old friends and comrades, whom I had not seen in a while. We told old army stories and recalled those we served with, as tends to happen at such affairs. :) The evening ended with a toast to the Republic of Singapore, and Auld Lang Syne.  

We started the ROSC to train reservist (NSmen) officers to take on senior leadership roles in the SAF. Thanks to COL (NS) R Menon, the Commandant of the Singapore Command and Staff College, and his team of directing staff, the ROSC was a resounding success. 

Today the ROSC has become the Command and Staff Course (NS), and the staff college has been named after Dr Goh Keng Swee. But what hasn’t changed is the capability and resolve of our NSmen, and our commitment to them. 

MINDEF recently announced the recommendations of the Committee to Strengthen National Service, including the revamped NS HOME Awards, which will support our NSmen in housing, healthcare and education, and accident insurance. These are small gestures to thank our servicemen for their loyalty and service.  

A big thank you to all! - LHL

You may think trolling and flaming is a problem unique to Singapore, but it isn’t. 
 
In Europe, freedom of speech is considered almost a sacred virtue. Yet recently the European Court of Human Rights ruled that when a website publishes a controversial story that may attract defamatory or insulting comments, the website must anticipate this trolling and flaming, and be ready beforehand to remove these comments promptly. 

It is not the last word on the matter. But it reflects how societies are still finding the right balance between freedom of speech and responsible online behaviour. I agree with Minister Yaacob Ibrahim that freedom of speech does not come free from the need to be responsible for what one says, either online or offline. 

This is a tough problem to solve, but we need to develop our own ways to keep online conduct civil and constructive. – LHL

Attended the Opening Ceremony of the World Cities Summit, CleanEnviro Summit Singapore and Singapore International Water Week. This year, the events focused on developing liveable and sustainable cities.

We make modest contributions at these forums by sharing our experience. But we were actually just solving our own problems. :) If others find our solutions interesting, we are happy for them to come take a look. We share our knowledge willingly, because there are no secrets in running cities.

That’s what we did in Suzhou. In 1994, we started a partnership with the Suzhou municipal government to build the Suzhou Industrial Park. This included not just industrial estates, but also housing, infrastructure, urban development and commercial areas. The Park became a very successful model and is celebrating its 20th anniversary this year.

I’m happy Suzhou has won the Lee Kuan Yew World City Prize this year for its outstanding achievements in creating liveable, vibrant and sustainable urban communities. Congrats to Suzhou Mayor, Mr Zhou Naixiang, (shaking hands with me in photo) and the people of Suzhou! - LHL

The Parliament rounded up the debate on the President’s Address today. 
 
When governing a country, we are seldom lucky enough to have simple problems to solve. Usually the problem is complex, and has no perfect solution. Then we need to compromise and accept trade-offs. 

Take the CPF for example. As Tan Chuan-Jin told MPs yesterday, the CPF has served many of our housing, medical and retirement needs. But people are living longer, and their retirement needs will grow. How can CPF provide adequately for them? Who will bear the costs? We have been thinking about this for some time, together with the Pioneer Generation Package. By the National Day Rally, I should be ready to share more. 
 
Thanks to all of you who have written on this page to express your support (e.g., Suhana Ismail, Chun Zheng), especially those who wrote on the vital question of keeping politics constructive. 

The debate is over, but we will continue discussing and working on these issues outside of Parliament. I hope more people, including our youths, can be part of the “problem-solving-democracy” Lawrence Wong talked about. That is the way to build a better Singapore for everyone. 
 
- LHL

Spoke in Parliament this afternoon. I reported the progress we had made since the 2011 elections. We have stabilised house prices, improved public transport, and managed the inflow of immigrants and foreign workers. 

I explained our agenda for the rest of this govt’s term. We will keep Singapore a leading city in the world, where every citizen can lead a fulfilling life. We are strengthening social safety nets, such as with MediShield-Life, and improving retirement adequacy. We must also remain an open and mobile community, so every citizen has the opportunity to do well whatever their family backgrounds. 

I also explained what constructive politics means: effective policies, good leaders, robust debates, high standards of integrity, and staying united despite our differences. Leaders must take a stand, and take responsibility for what they say and do.

After my speech Mr Low Thia Khiang rose to contest what I had said. We had a vigorous exchange. I explained my view that the opposition fell short of their role in Parliament. Naturally Mr Low found reasons to disagree.

My government will keep on working with Singaporeans to build a better future for ourselves and our families. - LHL

Glad many MPs spoke in support of the President’s Address on the first day of the debate. Many, especially govt MPs, offered ideas to improve or change policies.

MPs generally supported the Government’s plans to improve people’s lives. But they had specific suggestions to help different groups of people. Some wanted more support for professionals, managers and executives (PMEs). Others suggested improvements to the CPF system to give older Singaporeans peace of mind in their retirement. Several urged more help for the lower-income and disadvantaged groups. We will look into these suggestions carefully.

Constructive politics is key to realising our dreams. The purpose of politics is to make a difference to people’s lives, to build a better Singapore. Politics purely for the sake of power, without any notion of what we want Singapore to become, will lead us to disaster.

This clip shows an exchange between Mr Low Thia Khiang and SMS Indranee Rajah on this important point.

Look forward to hearing more views tomorrow. I will be speaking on Wednesday. - LHL

I came across this interesting piece about how the Chinese language is changing in China. People are using English words in spoken and written Chinese directly, without translating them into Chinese equivalents, or even transliterating them into similar sounding Chinese characters.  It is easier to say GDP than 国内生产总值, and Wifi is Wifi. 

This is causing controversy in China. Some think it is the practical thing to do – everybody knows what Wifi is, so why invent some unfamiliar Chinese term for the same thing? But others feel that the pure Chinese language is being polluted with foreign words. After all, some translations have been successful – Coca Cola 可口可乐 has a very appropriate meaning, and translating email into 电邮 is neat and succinct.

The same thing is happening to other languages too. If you listen to Malay spoken in Malaysia, or Tamil in India, you will often hear English words mixed in.

The reality is that a language is a live, changing thing. It constantly absorbs words, concepts and usages from foreign languages, so long as people are using it in their daily lives. Otherwise it becomes a dead language, studied by scholars but not spoken by ordinary people anymore, like Latin or Sanskrit.

We pay a lot of attention to languages in Singapore. We are doing our utmost to keep our mother tongues alive. These are live languages to be used, so we should accept that they will evolve and change over time. We need to speak and write them correctly, but also colloquially. Then we will really be cool, or as we say in Mandarin, 酷! :)

- LHL

Saddened to learn that Dr Dixie Tan, former MP for Ulu Pandan, had passed on. 
 
Dixie and I were from the same batch of MPs. We entered Parliament together in 1984. For many years before that, all the MPs had been male. Dixie, along with Dr Aline Wong and Mdm Yu-Foo Yee Shoon, were the only female MPs elected that year. They more than held their own, and stood out in the House.
 
Dixie was a hardworking MP who cared for her residents and spoke up for them in Parliament. She retired in 1991 to pursue a second career as a family and marriage therapist. She told me she derived great satisfaction from this. It was in keeping with her temperament and concern for others.
 
She was also an active volunteer. She founded the Association for Educationally Subnormal Children (later renamed the Association for Persons with Special Needs), and was Adviser to the Singapore Bank Employees’ Union. She received the Public Service Star for her community contributions, before she became an MP.
 
Dixie impressed with her quiet self-confidence, good sense, and gentle resolve. She spoke softly, but pressed with conviction for what she believed in. Although her sons had special needs, and needed her love and care, she was able to fulfil her public as well as family roles amply.
 
May Dixie rest in peace.
 
- LHL

[With Dr Dixie Tan (left) in September 1984, when we were preparing to stand for election. The late Mr Ong Teng Cheong had invited us to dinner at his home, where the picture was taken. / Photo credit: Ong Teng Cheong Collection, courtesy of National Archives of Singapore]

Met Hu Chunhua, the Party Secretary of Guangdong Province, for the first time today. He is spending three days here. He has visited Buona Vista community club, attended a Meet-the-People session with Chan Chun Sing and toured the Marina Bay Sands. He told me his visit has given him a better sense of how Singapore works, and what makes us tick.

Guangdong has transformed itself in the last 20 years. They talk about 腾笼换鸟 – clearing the cage and changing the bird, meaning changing from old industries to new ones; and 凤凰涅磐 – being reborn like the Phoenix from the ashes, meaning reinventing and upgrading the economy. Singapore is travelling on this path too. So I had a very good discussion with Hu, sharing our experiences and exchanging notes. 

Singapore enjoys extensive cooperation with Guangdong province. The Sino-Singapore Guangzhou Knowledge City project is progressing well. A large part of our trade and investment with China is actually with Guangdong. 

I look forward to visiting Guangdong in September, and seeing its progress since my last visit in 2006. – LHL

I was appalled to read about those who harassed the organisers of the Philippine Independence Day celebrations, and spammed their Facebook page. They are a disgrace to Singapore.

Fortunately this appears to be the work of few trolls. Heartened that many sensible Singaporeans condemn this thuggish behaviour, and support Tan Chuan-Jin’s stand on this issue <http://on.fb.me/1ml0Y4u>. 

We must treat people in Singapore the way we ourselves expect to be treated overseas. Many Singaporeans live overseas, and are warmly welcomed in their adopted homes. Parliament prorogues (i.e. takes a mid-term break) today until 16 May. 

Parliament has been busy these past 2½ years. We have had vigorous and valuable debates on our White Papers on Ministerial Salaries and Population. We have passed Budgets that include major economic and social policies, including the Pioneer Generation Package, GST Vouchers, and Workfare enhancements. MPs have filed many questions to obtain information, press for actions, and solve their voters’ problems.

Parliament is where the most important national issues are debated and decided. Our sittings are not as fiery as some other legislatures, but the duty of government is to manage affairs responsibly and soberly, and not to create entertainment and excitement.

Singapore is in transition. We are adjusting to new domestic needs while navigating an uncertain international environment. When Parliament re-opens on 16 May, we will hear the President’s Address, and discuss strategies for creating a brighter future and a better Singapore for all. - LHL

The students had interesting perspectives on this Budget and shared ideas on what they would like to see next year.

I explained to them that the purpose of the Budget is to decide on where and how the Government is going to raise and spend its money for the year. 

This year, we had two main goals:

First, we want to grow our economy, to create more and better jobs for Singaporeans, and to give citizens more opportunities to upgrade themselves and improve their lives.

Second, we are building a fair and equitable society. The Budget contains schemes to help people afford medical treatment, public transport, education, housing, etc. It also recognises our Pioneer Generation through a special healthcare package (http://www.singaporebudget.gov.sg/budget_2014/pgp.aspx).

Was saddened to hear of the passing of Abdul Ghani Abdul Hamid, a member of our Pioneer Generation.

Mr Lee Kuan Yew said in 1962: “The acid test of any legal system is not the greatness or grandeur of its ideal concepts, but whether in fact it is able to produce order and justice in the relationships between man and man and between man and the State”. 

This is still true today. 

Last night I attended the Legal Service Dinner. These officers support our ministries, staff the Attorney General’s Chambers, and run the courts. Their work has become heavier and more complex over time. We now have nearly 600 Legal Officers.  

We are introducing two separate career tracks for mid-level officers to specialise – a Legal Track (ministry and AG’s Chambers work) and a Judicial Track (court work). 

I hope that our Legal Service will remain firmly anchored to our values, understand our circumstances and needs, and contribute to Singapore’s continued success. – LHL

We needn’t accept everything the writer says. But her article is still a good reminder to us to be kinder and more gracious to one another.

We have made progress over the years with the courtesy campaign, the Singapore Kindness Movement, and efforts in our schools. We often read newspaper letters about acts of kindness to strangers. But we can still do much better.

It takes effort from each of us, but it is important and worthwhile. Our pace of life is fast, and we all feel the pressures of living in a city. But all the more we should try harder to respect and help one another. It will make life more pleasant for all of us. – LHL

Met Residents’ Committee volunteers from all over Singapore this afternoon at the National Residents’ Committee (RC) Convention. 

RCs have come a long way since they were set up in 1977. Their job then (and now) was to preserve the kampong spirit as people moved from kampongs to HDB flats. But today residents lead busier lives, and RC programmes have to adapt to changing lifestyles and needs.

We wrapped up the Committee of Supply debate today. MPs spent 7 days going through the Ministries one by one, questioning ministers, raising issues, and championing ideas they feel passionate about. 

My thanks to all MPs for their active participation, and to ministers for working hard to listen, reassure, and explain. I am heartened by the general support for Budget 2014. 
 
Yesterday and today, Gan Kim Yong and Chan Chun Sing explained how we are strengthening social safety nets so that no one gets left behind. One key initiative is MediShield Life, which will cover every Singaporean, throughout his or her life.

Premiums for MediShield Life will be affordable for all, especially the elderly and the low-income. 
 
The Govt will bear most of the initial costs of universal coverage under MediShield Life. We will also introduce permanent subsidies for lower- to middle-income groups. For those who despite this help can’t afford their remaining share of premiums, Medifund will provide additional assistance. 
 
After all the subsidies, most households should be able to pay their MediShield premiums using just half of their Medisave contributions. 

Lower- to middle-income households should pay either the same or less premiums for MediShield Life as they are paying for MediShield today. 

The Pioneer Generation will be fine too. Effectively, those aged 80 and above today will have their premiums fully covered. Younger Pioneers (aged 65 – 79) on MediShield today will pay half of current premiums, but get better coverage. 
 
MediShield Life depends on everyone chipping in to share the burden, to take collective responsibility to protect one another. While MediShield Life gives us peace of mind for our health costs, let’s all do our part to stay healthy and avoid getting sick. This is the best way to keep health costs low, live long and live well.
 
- LHL

MPs discussed housing, transport, arts and heritage, and the environment yesterday and today in the Committee of Supply. Here are a few highlights.

Khaw Boon Wan shared plans to look into more ways for elderly residents to monetise their HDB flats, to support vulnerable families (e.g. divorcees with children), to enable more extended families to live near one another. MND had fewer cuts (items raised by MPs for discussion) this year than previous years, which hopefully shows that people are less worried about housing!

Lui Tuck Yew described what we are doing to reduce train disruptions, and cut waiting and travel time. We have bought more trains and will put more buses on the road, so as to service commuters better, especially during peak periods. 

Lawrence Wong announced plans to build more sports facilities all over the island, so that most Singaporeans will have sports facilities a short walk from home. The National Museum will have a new Wing, Play@NMS, dedicated to children and young families. We hope young Singaporeans will visit the Museum often, and grow up with fond memories of the Museum. (As I do – my grandmother used to regularly take me and my siblings to the National Museum. :) )

Vivian Balakrishnan announced an updated PSI index that takes into account PM 2.5 pollution, and an International Advisory Panel to advise the Government on what it can do about the haze under international law.

These are not easy issues, but if we continue working at them, we’ll continue improving our living environment and keeping Singapore a liveable city and an endearing home. 

- LHL

Paid my respects at the wake of Mr Lee Gek Seng, a founding member of the PAP.

Mr Lee was a union leader of the Singapore Postal and Telecoms Employees Union. He had helped to found the union in 1947. 

During the postmen’s strike in 1952, he worked with Mr Lee Kuan Yew, who was the union’s legal advisor.

So when Mr Lee Kuan Yew launched the PAP in Nov 1954, Mr Lee Gek Seng was in the first pro-tem Central Executive Committee, and later served as Deputy Secretary General.

Mr Lee was a community leader for many years in Jalan Besar, and later in Toa Payoh. MPs he worked with included Mr Chan Chee Seng and Dr Lee Boon Yang.

I had just met Mr Lee at the Pioneer Generation Tribute at the Istana last month. He came in a wheelchair, but was clearly very happy to be there. Now he has left us. 

– LHL

To create better jobs paying higher wages, and to build a fair and equitable society, we are restructuring our economy.

We are tightening up on foreign workers, and helping businesses to improve productivity. It is not always easy for businesses to keep up, especially our small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). 

But we must press on. We are helping our businesses upgrade in practical ways. Here are some schemes we talked about in Parliament.

(Lim Hng Kiang) The Nanyang Additive Manufacturing Centre at NTU has the latest 3D printers which can print metal objects and even human tissue. It will do R&D projects together with businesses, to develop commercial applications for this technology. 

(Teo Ser Luck) JTC is developing a hub for incubators and start-ups in promising industries like biomedical sciences, electronics and engineering. JTC LaunchPad@one-north will be a common space for like-minded entrepreneurs to share ideas and make deals. 
 
(Tan Chuan-Jin) New technologies like data analytics, robotics and 3D are taking off. We will educate and train you, to master the knowledge and skills, seize the opportunities, and build rewarding careers. 

Singapore will always be a nation of opportunity for all of us. - LHL

During the Budget debate, we always pay attention to local issues – healthcare, housing, public transport. But we must not lose sight of what is happening in the outside world, and how faraway events can affect us. Take for example the crisis in Ukraine, which Minister K Shanmugam Sc talked about in his speech yesterday (http://bit.ly/1e1SDg7). 

Ukraine is bigger than Singapore, but much smaller than its neighbour, Russia. For the last few months, the country has been in turmoil. Two weeks ago, President Yanukovich fled, and his pro-Russian government collapsed. Russian troops then intervened in the Crimea, a part of Ukraine that used to belong to Russia, and where Russia still has a naval base. 

If war breaks out in Ukraine, the global economy will be affected, and so will ours. We condemn any unprovoked invasion of a sovereign country, whatever the pretext. All countries, big and small, must observe international law. This is vital to a small country like Singapore. 

Russia is a nuclear power. Ukraine signed a treaty in 1994 with Russia, the US and UK to give up its nuclear weapons, in exchange for which the US and Russia agreed not to use force against Ukraine. Yet Ukraine is in this predicament today. 

The Ukraine crisis reminds us that small countries must defend themselves, and cannot rely solely on international treaties or the promises of others. That is why we must always maintain a strong SAF and Home Team. We must also have a capable MFA to strengthen our ties with friends and allies. Only then can Singapore be safe and secure.

- LHL

I’m glad this year’s Budget has been well received. MPs from both sides of the House supported the Budget, especially the Pioneer Generation Package. They shared stories of their own parents or grandparents, who belonged to the special generation which built Singapore. They made useful suggestions to improve the Package and other Budget initiatives. We will consider their ideas carefully.

The govt can afford the Pioneer Generation Package because we have been careful with our finances. But govt spending is going up – on healthcare, infrastructure, and an ageing population. We are alright for the next few years. Beyond that, we must think about raising more revenues. 

We must never fall into the same hole as so many other countries, spending more than they earn, dragging down the economy and burdening future generations. If we keep our economy vibrant, and live within our means, we can continue providing assurance to all, while keeping ours a nation of opportunities. – LHL

Was saddened to learn of the passing of another Pioneer Generation leader, Mr Chua Sian Chin, who was an MP and Minister for many years. 

Like quite a few others, he was born in Malaya, in his case Malacca, but came to Singapore to seek his future and make his home. While studying law in London, he met Mr Lee Kuan Yew, who was speaking to the Singapore and Malayan students there. Later he recounted what a profound impression Mr Lee made on him and his fellow students.

Mr Chua held several important appointments in the Cabinet from 1968 to 1984 – Health, Home Affairs, Education. As MP for MacPherson for 23 years, he groomed many grassroots volunteers, including several who have continued serving till today.

Mr Chua’s passing is a sad loss to us all. Our thoughts are with his family during this time of sorrow. – LHL

Was sorry to learn of the passing of Haji Mohamed Ariff Suradi. He belonged to our Pioneer Generation of leaders, who set Singapore on the path of growth and success.

Hj Mohamed Ariff was a Legislative Assemblyman while we were in Malaysia, and then a Member of Parliament after we became independent. He served in Ulu Pandan and later Kampong Kembangan. Those were tumultuous times, with racial riots, and strong ethnic tensions. Because Hj Mohamed Ariff and the other PAP Malay leaders of his generation stood firm, and supported the PAP’s vision of a multi-racial Singapore, we were able to build the harmonious society that we have today.

When we held the Pioneer Generation Tribute event at the Istana a few weeks ago, I had asked if Hj Mohamed Ariff could come, but was told that he was unwell and could not make it. His passing marks another step in the passage of generations.

Our condolences to Hj Mohamed Ariff’s family. May he rest in peace. – LHL

Saya berdukacita dengan pemergian Haji Mohamed Ariff Suradi. Beliau tergolong di kalangan Generasi Pemimpin Perintis kita yang mengorak langkah untuk Singapura mencapai kemajuan dan kejayaan.

Hj Mohamed Ariff merupakan Anggota Dewan Perundangan ketika kita sebahagian dari Malaysia dan kemudian seorang Anggota Parlimen selepas kita merdeka. Beliau telah berkhidmat di Ulu Pandan dan kemudian Kampong Kembangan. Keadaan begitu getir ketika itu dengan rusuhan kaum dan hubungan antara kaum yang tegang. Namun berkat keteguhan Hj Mohamed Ariff dan para pemimpin Melayu PAP lain yang seangkatan dengannya, menyokong visi Singapura yang berbilang bangsa, kita mampu membina masyarakat harmoni yang kita nikmati hari ini.

Ketika kami mengadakan majlis menjunjung budi Generasi Perintis di Istana beberapa minggu lalu, saya bertanya jika beliau boleh hadir tetapi saya diberitahui beliau uzur dan tidak dapat hadir. Pemergian beliau adalah satu lagi petanda peralihan generasi.

Salam takziah kami kepada keluarga Haji Mohamed Ariff Suradi. Kami turut berduka atas pemergian beliau. – LHL

DPM Tharman Shanmugaratnam presented Budget 2014 this afternoon. It acknowledges our debt to the Pioneer Generation, and helps to prepare our economy and society for the future. 

The Budget gives specifics of the Pioneer Generation Package that I announced two weeks ago. These men and women made great sacrifices to build today’s Singapore. Now, it’s our turn to take care of them. 

There are enhanced schemes to help companies (especially SMEs) upgrade, adopt IT, and raise productivity.

Employer CPF contributions will go up, to help build up our Medisave savings. 

Healthcare will become more affordable. Lower- and middle-income patients will enjoy higher subsidies for outpatient care at polyclinics and specialist outpatient clinics.

We will give more support to disabled children and their families, through early intervention programmes. 

A GST voucher – Cash for Seniors, U-Save top-ups and S&CC rebates, will help households with the cost of living.

I hope we can work together and embrace the “can-do”, resilient and united spirit of our Pioneer Generation to achieve the best for Singapore. 
 
Budget 2014 contains much more. Visit www.Singaporebudget.gov.sg for more details of the schemes and incentives, and how you can benefit from them. – LHL

PM Lee Hsien Loong speaking to the media, after his dialogue with Malay/Muslim community leaders on the tudung issue, on 25 January 2014.
PM Lee Hsien Loong bercakap kepada media di akhir sesi dialog dengan wakil masyarakat Melayu/Islam mengenai isu tudung pada 25 Januari 2014.

The issue of wearing the tudung (headscarf in Malay) by Muslim women is an important matter for many Muslims in Singapore. This evening I met community and religious leaders, together with some Ministers and MPs, for a candid and fruitful dialogue. Snapped this pic of the participants at the end – all in good spirits! 

I told the group that I fully appreciate their desire to allow Muslim women in uniform to wear the tudung. But a larger issue is at stake: the sort of society we aspire to be. Singapore is a multi-racial, multi-religious and harmonious society. Minorities are fully integrated into the mainstream, but have full opportunities to maintain their identities and practise their faiths. So I am also mindful how crucial it is for us to strengthen our cohesion, and maintain the relaxed confidence and trust that benefits us all, especially the minorities.

On the tudung issue, the position is not frozen. Attitudes will shift and arrangements will get updated. We have gradually evolved over the last decade. Many statutory boards now have uniforms that allow Muslim staff to wear the tudung, e.g., LTA, NEA. In 5, 10 years’ time, I am confident that we will not be in the same situation as today.

It is best that we continue evolving gradually and carefully. The racial harmony we enjoy is not perfect, but it is more precious and more fragile than we think. Let’s work hard to strengthen it, so that all races can live happily together as one united people. – LHL

Isu tudung adalah isu penting bagi ramai orang Islam di Singapura. Petang tadi saya dan beberapa Menteri serta Anggota Parlimen telah bertemu dengan wakil-wakil masyarakat dan pemimpin agama. Perbincangan kami berlangsung secara terus terang, dan dari hati ke hati. Lihat gambar para peserta yang saya petik di akhir sesi – semuanya dalam semangat muhibbah! 

Saya tekankan kepada para peserta bahawa saya akur hasrat mereka untuk membenarkan wanita Islam di sektor seragam memakai tudung. Tetapi isu lebih besar harus difikirkan: Apakah bentuk masyarakat yang kita inginkan? 

Singapura adalah sebuah masyarakat berbilang bangsa dan agama yang harmoni. Kaum minoriti sebati dengan masyarakat lebih besar tetapi memiliki peluang sepenuhnya untuk kekalkan identiti dan amalkan agama masing-masing. Jadi saya sedar betapa gentingnya untuk memperkukuh ikatan kita bersama dan mengekalkan keyakinan dan kepercayaan yang mendatangkan manfaat untuk kita semua, lebih-lebih lagi kaum minoriti.

Dalam isu tudung, keadaan yang kita lihat hari ini tidak akan kekal begini. Sikap akan berubah dan dikemaskinikan. Sepanjang sedekad lalu, ada kemajuan yang bertahap dalam isu ini. Kini, banyak badan berkanun membenarkan kakitangan mereka memakai tudung bersama pakaian seragam misalnya LTA, NEA. Dalam 5, 10 tahun lagi, saya yakin keadaan akan berubah, tidak seperti hari ini. 

Sebaiknya kita terus bergerak secara bertahap dan berhati-hati. Sesungguhnya keharmonian kaum yang kita nikmati tidak sempurna, ia sebenarnya lebih rapuh dan berharga dari apa yang kita sedari. 

Ayuh kita berusaha gigih untuk memperkukuhkannya supaya semua kaum boleh hidup bersama-sama dengan selesa sebagai satu warga yang bersatu-padu. - LHL

Saddened to hear of the passing of Sir Run Run Shaw, at the ripe old age of 107. He lived in Hong Kong, but was a good friend of Singapore. The Shaw Brothers (Run Run and Runme) were a major player in our movie industry. Generations of Singaporeans enjoyed their movies and TV shows. The Shaw Foundation has contributed to many charitable causes here.

I first met Sir Run Run in 1985, when I chaired an Economic Committee to review our economy. He flew in specially to share his ideas on growing media-related services with Dr Tony Tan (then Minister for Trade and Industry) and me. Subsequently when I visited Hong Kong, I would often meet Sir Run Run for a meal, and to learn from his thoughtful views about Hong Kong and the world.

Sir Run Run will be fondly remembered by Singaporeans. My deepest condolences to Mrs Mona Shaw and her family. – LHL

Attended the presentation of Teck Ghee CCC Bursary awards to 493 students yesterday. This is our community effort to help students from needy families. 

The Bursaries were funded by donors who bid in auctions at the Seventh Month dinners. Many are from local SMEs. We thank them for their generosity and public spirit. 

To all the recipients – I hope you make good use of the bursaries and continue to study hard! - LHL
